revision.text:
'''120 Sports''' is an [[internet television]] service, operated as a joint venture between [[Time Inc.]], [[Chicago White Sox#Silver Chalice subsidiary|Silver Chalice]], [[MLB Advanced Media]], and the [[National Hockey League]]. The service produces and streams sports news and highlight content catered towards digital platforms and a young adult audience
== History == 120 Sports was announced on February 20, 2014 by [[Time Inc.]] as a branch of its magazine ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', with financial backing by [[MLB Advanced Media]], the [[National Hockey League]], and [[Chicago White Sox#Silver Chalice subsidiary|Silver Chalice]]. Initially, the service focused on streaming sports news and highlights, particularly from its partners as well as the [[NBA]] and [[NASCAR]]. The name of the service came from its original concept, as these videos would be only two minutes long.<ref name=ct>{{cite news|title=Time Inc, sports leagues to launch online streaming sports network|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-02-21/news/sns-rt-timeinc-120sports--20140221_1_time-inc-sports-network-sports-illustrated|accessdate=August 17, 2016|work=Chicago Tribune|agency=Reuters|publisher=Chicago Tribune Media Group|date=February 21, 2014}}</ref>
On June 25, 2014, 120Sports launched a daily schedule of live studio programming; president Jason Coyle stated that the service wanted to "create a daily habit, where you'll check us multiple times a day and have as long a viewing session as possible". The service was designed to appeal to [[millennial]]s. To avoid succumbing to [[East Coast bias|regional bias]], the network hired reporters from across the country; executive vice president Matt Carstens stated 120 Sports "wanted to have a work base that is diverse in every way — diverse in the sports they follow, diverse in the teams they follow — to prevent any sort of bias".<ref name="ct0">{{cite news|last1=Channick|first1=Robert|title=All-digital 120 Sports kicking off streaming network|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-06-25/business/ct-digital-sports-network-0625-biz-20140625_1_video-driven-sports-reports-120-sports-silver-chalice|accessdate=August 17, 2016|work=Chicago Tribune|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=June 25, 2014}}</ref> A morning show, ''120 Morning Run'', was launched on July 2, 2014. It is hosted by Chicago sports talk veterans Laurence Holmes and Dylan McGorty.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Channick|first1=Robert|title=120 Sports is adding a live morning show|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-07-02/business/chi-120-sports-a-live-morning-show-20140701_1_video-driven-sports-reports-all-digital-sports-network-120-sports|accessdate=August 17, 2016|work=Chicago Tribune|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=July 2, 2014}}</ref>
On April 13, 2017, it was announced that Silver Chalice had partnered with [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]] to merge [[Campus Insiders]], 120 Sports, and Sinclair's syndication service and linear digital television channel [[American Sports Network]] into a new linear and digital sports network, which is now known as Stadium.<ref name="bandc-asnrevamp">{{cite web|title=Sinclair Partners to Revamp, Relaunch Sports Network|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/local-tv/sinclair-partners-revamp-relaunch-sports-network/164905|website=Broadcasting and Cable|accessdate=15 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="sbn-asnrelaunch">{{cite web|title=American Sports Network, Campus Insiders, and 120 Sports Announce Mega-Merger Deal|url=http://www.underdogdynasty.com/2017/4/13/15295142/american-sports-network-campus-insiders-120-sports-announce-mega-merger-deal-tv-online-streaming-g5|website=Underdog Dynasty (SBNation)|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=15 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="sunherald-stadium">{{cite web|title=Is Twitter the new home for Southern Miss football?|url=http://www.sunherald.com/sports/college/conference-usa/university-of-southern-mississippi/article148154494.html|website=Sun Herald|accessdate=12 May 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sports television networks in the United States]]
{{Television-stub}}

revision.comment: Change from 1800s, ambiguous (decade or century). Citation refers to its heyday and quotes 1885/6 sources
revision.text:
{{Infobox amusement park | name = Al-Tro Island Park | image = | caption = | resort = | location = [[Menands, New York|Menands]] | location2 = [[New York (state)|New York]] | location3 = United States | coordinates = {{coord|42.679501|-73.727274|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | theme = | homepage = | owner = | general_manager = Manager Rosen | operator = | opening_date = Late 19th century | closing_date = Early 1920s | previous_names = Pleasure Island, Lagoon Island, Dreamland | season = | visitors = | area = | rides = | coasters = | water_rides = | slogan = | footnotes = <ref name="ATU 2003">{{cite news|url=http://www.colonie.org/historian/altro/tu_article.pdf |title=Decades Later, Pleasure Island Resurfaces |work=Albany Times Union |date=September 16, 2003 |accessdate=July 14, 2012 |author=Grondahl, Paul |pages=A1, A4 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224083041/http://www.colonie.org/historian/altro/tu_article.pdf |archivedate=February 24, 2012 }}</ref> }} '''Al-Tro Island Park''' was an [[amusement park]] built in the late [[19th century]] in the [[Administrative divisions of New York#Village|village]] of [[Menands, New York|Menands]] near the border with [[Administrative divisions of New York#City|city]] of [[Albany, New York|Albany]], [[New York (state)|New York]]; formerly the park was known as Pleasure Island. The island has since been covered with fill and used for [[Interstate 787]].
== History == In the 1880s, thousands of visitors jammed Pleasure Island, also known as "Dreamland." In truth, it was not an actual island, but was separated from the mainland by the [[Erie Canal]].<ref name="ATU 2003" />
By [[Memorial Day]], 1907, Pleasure Island was built up and re-opened as Al-Tro Island Park, named for the two cities it was located between, Albany and [[Troy, New York|Troy]]. It featured 40-piece [[orchestra]] in a dance hall, a roller-skating rink, a [[roller coaster]], a [[movie theater|theater]] with 4,000 seats, its own [[miniature railroad]], a pony track and more than a hundred other attractions. The park even had its own police force consisting of 15 uniformed officers to maintain safety and order. A [[boardwalk]] extended the entire length of the island.<ref name="ATU 1907">{{cite news|url=http://www.colonie.org/historian/altro/record_article.pdf |title=Al-Tro Park in readiness for the public |work=Albany Times-Union |orig-year=May 27, 1907 |date=June 30, 1985 |accessdate=July 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205165740/http://www.colonie.org/historian/altro/record_article.pdf |archivedate=February 5, 2012 }}</ref>
By the early 1920s, Al-Tro Island Park began to fall out of favor due to changing tastes in leisure. No one knows exactly when it closed or what happened to it. Most agree that the park "vanished without a trace." The Mid-City Amusement Park was constructed as a replacement nearby on Broadway, also in Menands, but it too has since been destroyed.<ref name="ATU 2003" />
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Amusement parks in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct amusement parks in the United States]] [[Category:19th-century establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:1920s disestablishments in the United States]]
{{amusement-park-stub}}

{{use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Al Jazirah
الجزيرة | logo = شعار صحيفة الجزيرة السعودية.png | image = | caption = | type = Daily newspaper | format = [[Broadsheet (newspaper)|Broadsheet]] | owners = Mutlaq bin Abdullah | founder = Al Jazirah Corporation for Press, Printing and Publishing | publisher = Al Jazirah Corporation for Press, Printing and Publishing | editor = | chiefeditor = Khalid bin Hamd Al Malik | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{start date and age|1960}} | political = Conservative and pro-Islamic; pro-government | language = [[Arabic]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Riyadh]] | circulation = 123,097 (January–June 2013) | sister newspapers = ''Al Masaiya'' | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.al-jazirah.com/ ''Al Jazirah''] }} '''''Al Jazirah''''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] الجزيرة meaning ''The Peninsula'') is a daily [[Arabic]] newspaper published in [[Saudi Arabia]]. Its sister newspaper is ''Al Masaiya'', is the only afternoon newspaper in the country with limited influence and readership.{{cite book|last=Jerichow|first=Anders|title=The Saudi File: People, Power, Politics|year=1998|publisher=St. Martin's Press|location=New York|isbn=0-312-21520-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6e0OAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA209&lpg=PA209&dq=al+nadwa+newspaper+saudi+arabia&source=bl&ots=2FyEM-jXqB&sig=daa2U3jzM_KPCHFmNq5rCkQVBJ4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UVG1T_r4DKeQ4g}} The paper is published in broadsheet format{{cite web|title=Saudi publisher Al-Jazirah embarks on vast Goss Lifetime Support project|url=http://www.gossinternational.com/news/2013/03/19/newspaper-press-news/saudi-publisher-al-jazirah-embarks-on-vast-goss-lifetime-support-project-to-boost-print-capacity-and-flexibility/|work=Goss International|accessdate=4 February 2015|date=19 March 2013}} with 48 pages, both colour and black and white contents.{{cite book|author=Anthony Shoult|title=Doing Business with Saudi Arabia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=or08gGGX_toC&pg=PA277|accessdate=1 March 2013|date=1 May 2006|publisher=GMB Publishing Ltd|isbn=978-1-905050-67-3|page=277}} It has more than thirty national and international branches.{{cite news|title=The press in Saudi Arabia|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6176791.stm|accessdate=17 May 2012|work=BBC News|date=13 December 2006}} ==History and profile== ''Al Jazirah'' was established in 1960 by Al Jazirah Corporation.{{cite web|title=Al Jazirah Company |url=http://www.al-jazirah.com.sa/en/ |publisher=Al Jazirah Company |accessdate=16 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501152130/http://www.al-jazirah.com.sa/en/ |archivedate=1 May 2012 }} The chairman of the newspaper is Mutlaq bin Abdullah. [[Othman Al Omeir]] who currently owns the liberal Arabic e-newspaper ''[[Elaph]]'' was a member of the paper's board of directors.{{cite web|last=Morris|first=Sam|title=New Nomination List for 2012 Media Awards|url=http://www.ncfpeace.org/drupal/node/736|publisher=The Next Century Foundation|accessdate=2 June 2012|date=17 January 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531013107/http://www.ncfpeace.org/drupal/node/736|archive-date=31 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Furthermore, he was a sport correspondent in the early 1970s and later, London correspondent of the paper.{{cite web|title=UAE mediamen win awards|url=http://www.uae-tour.com/article/555/2/|publisher=Karma Tourism|accessdate=2 June 2012|date=27 April 2007}} In 1977, Abdel Rahman Al Rashid was appointed editor-in-chief of the daily, who also served as a correspondent and later as its [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] bureau chief from 1981 to 1985.{{cite web|title=Abdel Rahman Al Rashid|url=http://www.ecssr.com/CDA/en/ProfileBank/ViewProfile/0,,748,00+en-USS_01DBC.html|publisher=The Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research|accessdate=26 February 2013}} The current editor-in-chief of the newspaper is Khalid bin Hamd Al Malik.{{cite news|title=Saudi Newspapers Editors-in-Chief to SANA: Syrian-Saudi summit gave a strong momentum for developing bilateral relations|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Saudi+Newspapers+Editors-in-Chief+to+SANA%3A+Syrian-Saudi+summit+gave+a...-a0212387921"|work=Syrian Arab News Agency|accessdate=19 May 2012|date=8 October 2009}}{{cite book|title=Who's Who in the Arab World 2007-2008|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NHCQBAFMwawC&pg=PA71|accessdate=12 September 2014|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-093004-7|page=71}} ''Al Jazirah'' is considered by Anti-defamation League as very conservative as well as pro-Islamic.{{cite web|title=Arab media review. Anti-semitism and other trends|url=http://www.adl.org/Anti_semitism/arab/arab-media-review-July-December2010.pdf|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|accessdate=16 May 2012|date=July–December 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119200951/http://www.adl.org/Anti_semitism/arab/arab-media-review-July-December2010.pdf|archive-date=19 January 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The paper is also described as pro-government.{{cite web|title=The Saudi Press: Profiles of individual papers|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=91RIYADH3320|work=Wikileaks|accessdate=17 May 2012|date=6 April 1991}} ==Circulation== The paper is said to have a limited circulation and is not widespread in contrast to the other Saudi papers. However, it is widely distributed in [[Saudi Arabia]] and in other [[Arab countries|Arab]] and [[European countries]]. [[Global Investment House]] reported the market share of the paper as around 6.0% in November 2009.{{cite web|title=Saudi Research and Marketing Group|url=http://mec.biz/term/uploads/SRMG_03112009.pdf|publisher=Global Investment House|accessdate=28 May 2012|date=November 2009}} In 2008, ''Al Jazirah'' became the first Saudi daily which reported its subscription numbers and sales.{{cite web|title=For the first time in Saudi press history Al-jazirah newspaper announces subscription, sales numbers|url=http://www.bi-me.com/main.php?id=22150&t=1|work=Business Intelligence|accessdate=16 September 2013|author=Moussa Ahmad|location=Saudi Arabia|date=6 July 2008}} It is also the first Saudi newspaper to announce its circulation figures quoting the National Distribution Company, a third party company owned equally by Saudi newspapers. The paper underwent its first circulation audit in November 2009.{{cite web|title=Arab Media Outlook 2009-2013|url=http://www.fas.org/irp/eprint/arabmedia.pdf|publisher=Dubai Press Club|accessdate=19 May 2012|year=2010}} ''Al Jazirah'' had a circulation of 85,000 copies in 2001.{{cite web|title=World Press Trends|url=http://www.wan-press.org/ecrire/upload/wpt2004.pdf|work=World Association of Newspapers|accessdate=8 February 2015|location=Paris|date=2004}} The daily's circulation was given as 93,000 by Western media observers in 2002.{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia|url=http://www.pressreference.com/Sa-Sw/Saudi-Arabia.html|publisher=Press References|accessdate=16 May 2012}} The estimated circulation of the paper in 2003 was 80,000 copies.{{cite book|author=William A. Rugh|title=Arab Mass Media: Newspapers, Radio, and Television in Arab Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UGfbluSa4N8C&pg=PA61|accessdate=27 September 2013|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-98212-6|page=61}} Its 2007 circulation figure is given to be 110,000 by [[World Association of Newspapers]].{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia. Media market description|url=http://www.ihudaif.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/WORLD-ASSOCIATION-OF-NEWSPAPERS-%E2%80%93-WORLD-PRESS-TRENDS-2008.pdf|work=World Association of Newspapers|accessdate=16 May 2012|year=2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921062852/http://www.ihudaif.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/WORLD-ASSOCIATION-OF-NEWSPAPERS-%E2%80%93-WORLD-PRESS-TRENDS-2008.pdf|archive-date=21 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The confirmed circulation of the paper is reported to be more than 131,000 copies in June 2008. The circulation of the daily, which was confirmed by the [[BPA Worldwide|BPA]], was 125,415 copies for the last six months of 2011.{{cite news|title=BPA Worldwide 2nd for the six-month period ended 31 December 2011 Concurrent Release Data for the Middle East|url=http://www.bpaww.com/Bpaww_com/HTML/resources/2012/2012_ME_Concurrent_Release.pdf|accessdate=15 March 2013|work=BPA Worldwide|date=23 May 2012}} For the first six-month period of 2013 the paper had a circulation of 123,097 copies.{{cite web|title=BPA Worldwide Concurrent Release Data for the Middle East|url=http://www.buysafemedia.me/downloads/2013%20ME%20Concurrent%20Release%20%20June%202013%20final.pdf|work=BPA Worldwide|accessdate=2 October 2014|date=31 October 2013}} ==Influence and awards== It is argued that ''Al Jazirah'' is one of four leading Saudi daily newspapers along with ''[[Al-Watan (Saudi Arabia)|Al Watan]]'', ''[[Al Riyadh (newspaper)|Al Riyadh]]'' and ''[[Al Madina (newspaper)|Al Madina]]''. At the beginning of the 1990s, ''Al Jazirah'' and ''Al Riyadh'' competed against each other to be more influential than the other. The paper was awarded the best print prize in Asia by [[IFRA (publishing)|IFRA]] in [[Manila]] in 2007{{cite news|title=Saudi daily discloses circulation figures|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Saudi+daily+discloses+circulation+figures.-a0181012590|accessdate=15 March 2013|newspaper=Trade Arabia|date=6 July 2008}} and its website was awarded the digital excellence award by the Saudi Ministry of Communications and Information Technology in 2007.{{cite web|title=Al Jazirah Newspaper website is the best|url=http://www.topix.net/forum/world/saudi-arabia/TD80TJGHK6OEV1C8G|work=Topix|accessdate=18 September 2013|date=11 November 2007}} In addition, the editors of the paper were invited by the World Association of Newspapers to its 2007 conference held in [[South Africa]]. It was the first invitation of the association for a Saudi daily. ==Content == ''Al Jazirah'' usually publishes reports and interviews concerning national, Arab and international issues. The paper is mostly known for its daily supplements on different topics such as economy, sports, culture, computers, medicine and science.{{cite web|title=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.cityscapeabudhabi.com/_Admin/2012-Exhibitor-List/Al-Jazeera/ |publisher=Cityscape |accessdate=20 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521041621/http://www.cityscapeabudhabi.com/_Admin/2012-Exhibitor-List/Al-Jazeera/ |archivedate=21 May 2012 }} It also has a weekly supplement, ''Telecom and Digital World''. It also carries cartoons. The Arab Press Network states that the paper extensively covers the activities of [[House of Saud|the ruling Saudi family]] and adopts an uncritical approach towards the government's policies on most of its 60 daily pages. It is further discussed that its columnists and the debate they initiate are both weak.{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia |url=http://www.arabpressnetwork.org/newspaysv2.php?id=129 |work=The Arab Press Network |accessdate=19 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528072145/http://www.arabpressnetwork.org/newspaysv2.php?id=129 |archivedate=28 May 2012 }} Then [[Ministry of Health (Saudi Arabia)|minister of health]] [[Ghazi Abdul Rahman Al Gosaibi|Ghazi Al Gosaibi]]'s poem written for King Fahd, entitled "A Pen Bought and Sold", was published on the front page of the paper in 1984.{{cite news|last=Labonté|first=Hanna|title=Saudi Man of Letters and Cautious Reformer|url=http://en.qantara.de/Saudi-Man-of-Letters-and-Cautious-Reformer/8370c162/index.html|accessdate=4 September 2012|newspaper=Qantara|date=23 August 2010}} In the poem, Al Gosaibi indirectly accused the ruling elites, including [[Sultan bin Abdul Aziz|Prince Sultan]], then Minister of Defence, of corruption and Saudi Oger of improper tender activities regarding the public hospitals.{{cite journal|last=Abir|first=Mordechai|title=The Consolidation of the Ruling Class and the New Elites in Saudi Arabia|journal=Middle Eastern Studies|date=April 1987|volume=23|issue=2|pages=150–171|jstor=4283169|doi=10.1080/00263208708700697}} King Fahd fired him after reading the poem.{{cite news|title=Saudi reformer courted the king's attention with a poem|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/obituaries/saudi-reformer-courted-the-kings-attention-with-a-poem-20100829-13xia.html|accessdate=4 September 2012|newspaper=Brisbane Times|date=30 August 2010}} On 3 and 10 January 2002, a commentary by Muhammad bin Saad al Shuwayir was published in the paper. The commentary was entitled “Why Pork Is Forbidden?”. The author said that the transformation of [[Jews|the Jews]] into [[ape]]s and [[pig]]s was a punishment “because monkeys and pigs were considered among the lowliest of animals, in nature and manners.” He further stated that Jews always represent the human lowness, as expressed in [[Quran]].{{cite web|title=Arab countries 2003-4 |url=http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2003-4/arab.htm |publisher=Stephen Roth Institute |accessdate=16 May 2012 |year=2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513071317/http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2003-4/arab.htm |archivedate=13 May 2012 }} Jasser Abdulaziz al Jasser, a columnist of ''Al Jazirah'', criticised [[Russia]], especially [[Sergey Lavrov]], for supporting Assad regime's [[Alawite]] minority rule over a [[Sunni]] majority in [[Syria]] on 24 March 2012. Al Jasser argued that the same tactics used by Russia to oppress Muslim majority in [[Chechnya]] and the [[Caucasus]] were employed by Assad to oppress Sunni majority in Syria.{{cite web|last=Varulkar|first=H.|title=Rising Tensions between Saudi Arabia, Russia on Backdrop of Syrian Crisis|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/189/0/6246.htm|work=MEMRI|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=Inquiry and Analysis Series Report No.820|date=4 April 2012}} ''Al Jazirah'''s front page on 17 June 2012 was entirely in black and white, showing photographs of [[King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]] and late [[Crown Prince Nayef]], who died in [[Geneva]] on 16 June 2012.{{cite news|last=McDowall|first=Angus|title=Saudi king to bury Crown Prince, find successor|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/17/us-saudi-crownprince-idUSBRE85F05Z20120617|accessdate=17 June 2012|work=Reuters|date=17 June 2012}} ==Controversy== In September 2008, a reporter of the paper, Fahd al Jukhaidib, wrote an article in which he described frequent power cuts in [[Qubba]] in northern Saudi Arabia. The article also informed the readers about a protest in front of the government-owned electricity company as a result of power cuts experienced. Upon publication of his article, he was sentenced in October 2008 to two months in prison and 50 lashes for inciting the public to protest against a series of electric power reductions. He was free on appeal in 2009.{{cite web|title=Attacks on the Press 2010: Middle East and North Africa Developments|url=http://cpj.org/2011/02/attacks-on-the-press-2010-middle-east-north-africa-developments.php|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists (CPR)|accessdate=19 May 2012|date=February 2011}} ==Innovation== ''Al Jazirah'' seems not to be conservative in terms of using technology to provide advanced technological platforms to its readers. The paper is the first Saudi daily in launching online website that was formed in 1996.{{cite web|title=Electronic newspapers on the Internet|url=http://etheses.whiterose.ac.uk/3503/1/327651.pdf|work=University of Sheffield|accessdate=1 October 2013|author=Fayez A. Alshehri|format=PhD Thesis|date=July 2000}} It is also the first daily paper in [[the Middle East]] to launch mobile phone application which had more than 50,000 users in 2013. In addition to these technological innovations, ''Al Jazirah'' is also innovative in launching first online women’s daily covering female achievements in [[Saudi Arabia]], latest developments and other topics related to women.{{cite news|title=Saudi Arabia to have first online 'women' daily|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/region/saudi-arabia-to-have-first-online-women-daily-2011-09-27-1.420806|accessdate=16 May 2012|work=Emirates 7/24|date=27 September 2011}} In 2013, the daily cooperated with Goss International for press upgrade, refurbishment and relocation venture.{{cite web|title=Saudi publisher Al-Jazirah embarks on vast Goss Lifetime Support project to boost print capacity and flexibility|url=http://www.wan-ifra.org/articles/2013/04/03/saudi-publisher-al-jazirah-embarks-on-vast-goss-lifetime-support-project-to-boos|work=WAN IFRA|accessdate=16 September 2013|date=19 March 2013}} ==See also== [[List of newspapers in Saudi Arabia]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jazirah, Al}} [[Category:1960 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Publications established in 1960]] [[Category:Arabic-language newspapers]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Arab media]] [[Category:Media in Riyadh]]

revision.text:
{{about|the film|the album by Andrew Gold|All This and Heaven Too (album)}} {{Infobox film | name = All This, and Heaven Too | image = All_this_heaven_movieposter.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Anatole Litvak]] | producer = [[David Lewis (producer)|David Lewis]]
[[Anatole Litvak]] | screenplay = [[Casey Robinson]] | based on = {{based on|''All This, and Heaven Too'' (1938 novel)|[[Rachel Field]]}} | starring = [[Bette Davis]]
[[Charles Boyer]]
[[Barbara O'Neil]] | music = [[Max Steiner]] | cinematography = [[Ernest Haller|Ernie Haller]] | editing = [[Warren Low]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = {{Film date|1940|07|04}} | runtime = 141 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''All This, and Heaven Too''''' is a 1940 American drama film made by [[Warner Bros.]]-[[First National Pictures]], produced and directed by [[Anatole Litvak]] with [[Hal B. Wallis]] as executive producer. The [[screenplay]] was adapted by [[Casey Robinson]] from the novel by [[Rachel Field]]. The music was by [[Max Steiner]] and the cinematography by [[Ernest Haller|Ernie Haller]]. The film stars [[Bette Davis]] and [[Charles Boyer]] with [[Barbara O'Neil]], [[Jeffrey Lynn]], [[Virginia Weidler]], [[Helen Westley]], [[Walter Hampden]], [[Henry Daniell]], [[Harry Davenport (actor)|Harry Davenport]], [[George Coulouris]], [[Montagu Love]], [[Janet Beecher]] and [[June Lockhart]]. Rachel Field's novel is based on the true story of Field's great-aunt, Henriette Deluzy Desportes, a French governess who fell in love with the Duc de Praslin, her employer. When Praslin's wife, the Duchesse, was murdered, Henriette was implicated. It was a real-life scandal that contributed to the political turmoil before the [[French Revolution of 1848]] which deposed France's [[Louis Philippe I]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/574/All-This-and-Heaven-Too/articles.html|title=All This, and Heaven Too (1940) - Articles - TCM.com|author=|date=|work=Turner Classic Movies|accessdate=December 3, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/37793248|title=Henriette Desportes Field (1813-1875)|work=findagrave.com|accessdate=December 16, 2015}}Alexis de Tocqueville, Souvenirs, édition réalisée par Luc Monnier, Paris, Gallimard, 1942 ==Plot== [[Image:All This and Heaven Too trailer.JPG|200px|left|thumb|Screenshot of [[Charles Boyer]] and [[Bette Davis]] from the film's original trailer]] Mademoiselle Henriette Deluzy-Desportes ([[Bette Davis]]), a French woman, starts teaching at an American girls school. She is confronted by the tales and gossip about her that circulate among her pupils and, thus provoked, she decides to tell them her life story. Deluzy-Desportes is governess to the four children of the [[Charles de Choiseul-Praslin|Duc de Praslin]] ([[Charles Boyer]]) and the Duchesse de Praslin ([[Barbara O'Neil]]) in Paris during the last years of the [[Orleans monarchy]]. As a result of the Duchesse's constantly erratic and temperamental behavior, all that remains is an unhappy marriage, but the Duc remains with his wife for sake of their children. Deluzy-Desportes. with her warmth and kindness, wins the love and affection of the children and their father, but also the jealousy and hatred of their mother. She is forced to leave and the Duchess refuses to give her a letter of recommendation to future employers. The Duc confronts his wife and she invents alternative letters taking opposite attitudes, which in fact she has not written and does not intend to write. Her account enrages him and, at the breaking point, he kills her. The Duc de Praslin is in a privileged position; as a peer his case can only be heard by other nobles. He refuses to confess his guilt or openly to admit his love for Henriette Deluzy-Desportes, knowing that his fellow nobles wish to use such an admission to blame her for the murder by declaring that he was acting at her bidding. Ultimately the Duc takes poison to prevent himself from ever publicly proclaiming his love for Henriette, since he knows that would convict her; however, he lives long enough to reveal it to another of his servants, Pierre ([[Harry Davenport (actor)|Harry Davenport]]), a kindly old man who had warned the governess to leave the de Praslin household. With the Duc's death, the authorities accept that they have no evidence upon which to base a judgment that Henriette solicited the murder and she is released. Deluzy-Desportes had been recommended for the teaching position "in the land of the free" by an American minister, Rev. Henry Field ([[Jeffrey Lynn]]), to whom she had expressed a loss of faith while in prison. He proposes marriage, and it is implied that Henriette will accept. ==Cast== * [[Bette Davis]] as Henriette Deluzy * [[Charles Boyer]] as [[Charles de Choiseul-Praslin|Charles, Duke de-Praslin (referred to as Theo by his wife)]] * [[Barbara O'Neil]] as [[Francoise, Duchess de Praslin|Francoise "Fanny" Sebastiani de-Praslin (referring to herself as the Anglicized "Frances" in the letter she tells her husband she has written on behalf of Henriette.)]] * [[June Lockhart]] as Isabelle de Choiseul-Praslin * [[Virginia Weidler]] as Louise de Choiseul-Praslin * [[Ann E. Todd]] as Berthe de Choiseul-Praslin * Richard Nichols as Reynald de Choiseul-Praslin * [[Jeffrey Lynn]] as Reverend Henry Martyn Field * [[George Coulouris]] as Charpentier, the valet * [[Harry Davenport (actor)|Harry Davenport]] as Pierre, the grounds keeper * [[Janet Beecher]] as Miss Haines * [[Montagu Love]] as Army General [[Horace François Bastien, Baron Sébastiani|Horace Sébastiani]], Fanny's father * [[Helen Westley]] as Mme. LeMaire * [[Henry Daniell]] as Broussais * [[Walter Hampden]] as Pasquier * [[Ann Gillis]] as Emily Schuyler * [[Marilyn Knowlden]] as Marianna Van Horn ==Reception== The film was positively reviewed by critics. [[Bosley Crowther]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that film-goers willing to sit through the long running time "will find the film a source of much emotional satisfaction; others of less Spartan stamp will certainly protest that it wears out their patience in the telling of a comparatively uncomplicated tale. For the Warners are here handing out a tear-laden old-fashioned drama—and a very heavy one, too."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9903EEDA123EE432A25756C0A9619C946193D6CF|title=Movie Review - All This, and Heaven Too|last=Crowther|first=Bosley|authorlink=Bosley Crowther|date=July 5, 1940|website=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 2, 2015}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called it "film theatre at its best ... Casey Robinson in the scripting captured the quaintness of the manners and customs of Paris, in 1848, and succeeded admirably in retaining both spirit and characters of the novel, despite the necessity for much deletion of material."{{cite magazine|date=June 12, 1940|title=All This, and Heaven Too|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|location=New York|publisher=Variety, Inc.|page=14}} ''[[Film Daily]]'''s headline announced: "Dramatically powerful, beautifully mounted and superbly cast; film should be one of year's strongest box-office attractions."{{cite journal|date=June 17, 1940|title=Reviews of the New Films|journal=[[Film Daily]]|location=New York|publisher=Wid's Films and Folk Folk, Inc.|page=13}} ''[[Harrison's Reports]]'' wrote: "A powerful drama, with a strong appeal for women. The production is lavish, and the direction and performances are of the highest order."{{cite journal|date=June 22, 1940|title=''All This, and Heaven Too'' with Bette Davis, Charles Boyer, Jeffrey Lynn and Barbara O'Neil|journal=[[Harrison's Reports]]|page=98}} [[John Mosher (writer)|John Mosher]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' wrote that Litvak had swung the viewer into the historical setting "with all the romantic, profuse gusto at his command. I think a few of the scenes of governess and children might have been elided, for, with the sinister doings in the background, we can't forever sustain a nursery mood. In general, though, the long picture seems short, which, of course, is something very much in its favor."{{cite magazine|date=July 6, 1940|title=The Current Cinema|magazine=[[The New Yorker]]|location=New York|publisher=F-R Publishing Corp.|page=46}} ''All This, and Heaven Too'' placed fifth on ''Film Daily'''s year-end nationwide poll of 546 critics naming the best films of 1940.{{cite journal|date=January 14, 1941|title='Rebecca' wins Critics' Poll|journal=[[Film Daily]]|location=New York|publisher=Wid's Films and Folk Folk, Inc.|page=1}} ==Awards and honors== A successful, but expensive costume drama,Glancy, H. Mark. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2584/is_n1_v15/ai_16922275/pg_8 "Warner Bros film grosses, 1921-51"]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Historical Journal of Film, Radio and Television'' (March 1995); accessed December 16, 2015. it was nominated for three [[Academy Award]]s: [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]; O'Neil was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actress]]; and Ernest Haller for [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|All This, and Heaven Too (film)}} * {{IMDb title|0032194|All This, and Heaven Too}} * {{amg movie|1593}} * {{tcmdb title|id=574}} * {{AFI film|id=5055|title=All This, and Heaven Too}} {{Anatole Litvak}} {{DEFAULTSORT:All This, And Heaven Too}} [[Category:1940 films]] [[Category:1940s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic drama films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Max Steiner]] [[Category:Films directed by Anatole Litvak]] [[Category:Films set in Paris]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Films set in the 1840s]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Films based on American novels]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox journal | title = Annals of Improbable Research | cover = [[File:Cover Annals of Improbable Research.gif|250px]] | caption = | former_name = <!-- or |former_names= --> | abbreviation = Ann. Improbable Res. | discipline = Science humor | peer-reviewed = | language = English | editor = Marc Abrahams | publisher = Improbable Research, Inc. | country = [[United States]] | history = 1994 to present | frequency = Bimonthly | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSNlabel = | ISSN = 1079-5146 | eISSN = | CODEN = | JSTOR = | LCCN = | OCLC = | website = http://www.improbable.com | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = <!-- up to |link5= --> | link2-name = <!-- up to |link5-name= --> | boxwidth = }} The '''''Annals of Improbable Research''''' ('''''AIR''''') is a bi-monthly [[magazine]] devoted to scientific humor, in the form of a [[Satire|satirical]] take on the standard academic journal. ''AIR'', published six times a year since 1995, usually showcases at least one piece of scientific research being done on a strange or unexpected topic, but most of their articles concern real or fictional absurd experiments, such as a comparison of [[apples and oranges]] using [[infrared spectroscopy]]. Other features include such things as ratings of the [[cafeteria]]s at scientific institutes, fake classifieds and advertisements for a medical plan called HMO-NO, and a very odd letters page. The magazine is headquartered in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].
''AIR'' awards the annual science [[Ig Nobel Prize]]s, for ten achievements that "first make people laugh, and then make them think". ''AIR'' also runs the Luxuriant Flowing Hair Club for Scientists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://improbable.com/projects/hair/|title=Improbable Research|publisher=}}</ref>
== History ==
''AIR'' is not the first science parody magazine. The ''[[Journal of Irreproducible Results]]'' (''JIR'') was founded by [[Alex Kohn]] and [[Harry Lipkin]] in 1955, but most of its editorial staff, including editor [[Marc Abrahams]], left after the magazine was bought by publisher [[George Scherr]] in 1994. Scherr filed a number of court actions against ''AIR'', alleging that it was deceptively similar to the ''Journal'' and that it had stolen the name "Ig Nobel Prize", but these actions were unsuccessful.{{cn|date=February 2015}}
== Profile == Occasional ''AIR'' articles are factual and illuminating, if a bit offbeat. For example, in 2003 researcher-documentary producer [[Nick T. Spark]] wrote about the background and history of [[Murphy's Law]] in a four-part article, "Why Everything You know About Murphy's Law is Wrong".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.improb.com/airchives/paperair/volume9/v9i5/murphy/murphy0.html|title=Improbable Research|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014113936/http://www.improb.com/airchives/paperair/volume9/v9i5/murphy/murphy0.html|archivedate=2009-10-14|df=}}</ref> It was revised, expanded and later published in June 2006 as the book ''[[A History of Murphy's Law]]''. Another example: it was scientifically proved and waggishly reported that [[Scientific instrument|instruments]] can distinguish shit from [[Shinola (shoe polish)|Shinola]].<ref name="Cellannia">{{cite web |url=http://www.neatorama.com/2014/02/11/Spectroscopic-Discrimination-of-Shit-from-Shinola/ |title=Spectroscopic Discrimination of Shit from Shinola |author=Miss Cellania |date=February 11, 2014 |website=The Annals of Improbable Research |accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref>
== References == <references/>
== External links == * {{Official website}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Annals Of Improbable Research}} [[Category:American satirical magazines]] [[Category:American bimonthly magazines]] [[Category:English-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1995]] [[Category:Professional humor]] [[Category:American science and technology magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Ig Nobel Prize]]

{{Orphan|date=January 2015}}
{{Infobox presenter | name = Art Vincent | image = File:Art-Vincent-Jazz-DJ-speaks-to-crowd.jpg | image_size = | caption = Art Vincent, The Art of Jazz | birth_name = | birth_date = December 30, 1926 | birth_place = New Jersey | death_date = October 27, 1993 | death_place = California | show = The Art of Jazz | station = WFHA, WJLK, WRLB, WBGO | network = Backstage America | style = Jazz, interviews, talk | spouse(s) = }}
'''Art Vincent''' (December 30, 1926 - October 27, 1993) was an American jazz [[disc jockey]], concert producer and MC.
Vincent's broadcasting career spanned almost 30 years, from about 1960 through 1989. For much of that time, his program, "The Art of Jazz," aired on FM radio stations in New Jersey and was heard throughout the New York metropolitan area. Vincent was known for his smooth, resonant voice and encyclopedic knowledge of jazz. He championed jazz as a unique American art form on a par with western classical music.
A popular part of Vincent's radio broadcasts were his interviews with jazz greats, including [[Louis Armstrong]], Count Basie, Dave Brubeck, Ray Charles, Roy Eldridge, Duke Ellington, Tal Farlow, Art Farmer, Dizzie Gillespie, Jimmy Hamilton, Woody Herman, Richard "Groove" Holmes, Kenyon Hopkins, Stan Kenton, Gerry Mulligan, Peter Nero, Anita O'Day, Houston Person, Arthur Prysock, Lou Rawls, Don Sebesky, Jimmy Smith, Maxine Sullivan, Dr. Billy Taylor, Cal Tjader, Dinah Washington - and many others.
== Career ==
=== Radio and concert work ===
In 1956, Art Vincent developed the engineering plans for radio station WFHA. He and the station manager built WFHA from the ground up, completing it in 1959. Vincent became the station's chief engineer.<ref name="bb65">[http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC-YB/1965/B2-1965-YB-All.pdf 1965 Broadcasting Yearbook], p. B-97</ref> Around 1960, Vincent hosted his first broadcast on WFHA, a short-lived country music show. In 1961 he debuted his show, "The Art of Jazz."
Vincent broadcast a wide range of jazz recordings, from obscure to popular, including all genres, such as blues, Dixieland, manouche, bebop, contemporary, avant garde, etc. His shows often included contests and topical call-in segments.<ref name="nyt73">[https://www.nytimes.com New York Times], May 20, 1973 p. 101</ref> Jazz musicians were frequent in-studio guests, and Vincent would often play interviews he had recorded on-location. Through this rich and varied format, he strove to give his audience a quality listening experience.
Vincent was a maverick, refusing to follow some of the commercial broadcasting conventions of his day. He wouldn't speak over the beginning or end of a track, as was the norm for most DJs of the time. He would play several tracks in sequence, talk-free and without commercials. He declined to use management-endorsed playlists, instead developing unique playlists for each broadcast, based on his personal taste and feedback from listeners and musicians.
In 1967 Vincent moved his show to WJLK<ref name="bb67">[http://www.billboard.com/magazine-archive Billboard], Vol. 79 No. 17 April 29, 1967 p. 34</ref> and then to WRLB in 1969. He was popular in the NY area jazz community, and developed close relationships with fans and musicians alike. In 1972, he was a guest on the WOR television program, [[Joe Franklin|"The Joe Franklin Show,"]] along with flutist Bobbi Humphrey. Vincent also appeared on the Franklin show in the late 1960s or early 1970s, with his longtime friend, guitarist Tal Farlow. Additionally, Farlow composed theme music for the "Art of Jazz," writing two iterations of the theme: "Blue Art" and "Blue Art, Too." Farlow released the latter version on LP in 1981, much to the delight of Vincent and his fans.
Throughout his career, Vincent served as master of ceremonies for jazz concerts in New Jersey and elsewhere. In 1972, he was instrumental in starting what became a long-running jazz performance series at the Monmouth County Library in New Jersey.<ref name="njjs">[http://www.njjs.org/p/jjArchive/pdf/JJ3604.pdf Jersey Jazz, Journal of the New Jersey Jazz Society], April 2008, Vol 36 Issue 34 p. 20</ref> Vincent proposed the idea, and worked with library management to plan the first jazz concerts held in a U.S. public library reading room. He served as MC<ref name="tdr73">[http://209.212.22.88/data/rbr/1970-1979/1973/1973.05.15.pdf Daily Register], May 15, 1973 p. 25</ref><ref name="tdr74">[http://209.212.22.88/data/rbr/1970-1979/1974/1974.01.21.pdf Daily Register], January 21, 1974 p. 13</ref> for the initial three years of the series. Vincent also produced dozens of jazz concerts, at various venues, featuring performers such as Ruth Brown, Tal Farlow, Jimmy Heath, Etta Jones, Hank Jones, Wynton Marsalis, Ray Nance, Zoot Simms, Grady Tate, Teddy Wilson and other top players.<ref name="app89">[http://www.app.com Asbury Park Press], January 3, 1989 p. C6</ref> (Vincent can be heard as MC on the final track of guitarist Eddie Hazell's 1976 album "Take Your Shoes Off, Baby.") In the mid 1970s, with friends and colleagues, he started the AOJ & Company, a non-profit organization devoted to the promotion of jazz through live concerts, lectures and member networking.<ref name="tdr74b">[http://209.212.22.88/data/RBR/1970-1979/1974/1974.10.15.pdf Daily Register], October 15, 1974 p. 13</ref>
In 1979 the "Art of Jazz" show moved to NPR affiliate WBGO.<ref name="app80">[http://www.app.com Asbury Park Press], May 25, 1980 p. H14</ref> That same year, Vincent was heard on NPR hosting the EBU's French Jazz Festival (and again in 1981). In 1980, Vincent co-hosted the "Kool Jazz Festival" on NPR, live from Gracie Mansion in New York City. For the 1980-81 Golden Apple Awards, NYC Jazz Magazine readers nominated Vincent as the best DJ in the local jazz community. Vincent left WBGO in 1981, but continued to be active in the New York area jazz scene. In the mid-1980s he was heard on WBJB.<ref name="db84">[http://www.downbeat.com Down Beat], April 1984 p. 14</ref>
In the late 1980s, Vincent recorded a series of jazz musician interviews for Florida-based "Backstage America," a nationally syndicated program of arts-related news and commentary.<ref name="app89" /><ref name="db89">[http://www.downbeat.com Down Beat], January 1989</ref> Vincent's 15 minute "Jazzcast" segments were heard on radio stations in 17 states. He interviewed over 75 musicians for this series, including Toshiko Akiyoshi, Betty Carter, Buck Clayton, Panama Francis, Chico Hamilton, Milt Hinton, Clifford Jordan, Branford Marsalis, David "Fathead" Newman, and Sun Ra, to name a few.
Vincent's radio show received a mention in Batt Johnson's book, [http://www.battjohnson.com/pub_jazz.htm "What is This Thing Called Jazz?"] (iUniverse, 2000). Part of Vincent's 1973 interview with bassist Gene Ramey is quoted in Richard Lawn's textbook, [http://ricklawn.com/category/books/ "Experiencing Jazz"] (McGraw-Hill, 2006; Routledge, 2nd ed. 2012).{{clear|left}}
=== Writing ===
Art Vincent wrote the liner notes for several jazz albums, including:
: [[Soul Dance!|Houston Person, "Soul Dance!"]] Prestige Records, original release 1969 (reissued on CD as part of the two disc set "Truth!") : [[Right On Brother|Boogaloo Joe Jones, "Right On Brother"]] Prestige Records, original release 1970 (reissued on CD) : Ray Rivera, "Big City Blues" Zanzee Records, 1972 : [[Chromatic Palette|Tal Farlow, "Chromatic Palette"]] Concord Jazz, original release 1981 (reissued on CD; includes the theme music "Blue Art, Too")
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Vincent, Art}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:American radio DJs]] [[Category:Jazz radio presenters]] [[Category:NPR personalities]] [[Category:Radio personalities from New Jersey]] [[Category:Masters of Ceremonies]] [[Category:20th-century American musicians]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Basketball Pro Management |developer = [[Umix Studios]] |publisher = [[Umix Studios]] |designer = |engine = |released = (2012 [[Personal computer|PC]]): January 12, 2012
(2013 [[Personal computer|PC]]): February 15, 2013
(2014 [[Personal computer|PC]]): December 12, 2013
(2015 [[Personal computer|PC]]): November 19, 2014) |genre = [[Sports game]], [[Business simulation game|Business simulation]], [[Sports game#Management.2FSimulation|Sports Management]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Basketball Pro Management''''' (BPM) is a [[video game]] that gives the player the opportunity to manage the basketball team of his choice. This [[management game]] includes both European Championships and the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]. The last version is Basketball Pro Management 2015. [[Umix Studios]] and [[Cyanide (company)|Cyanide]] decided to create a new game for the season 2015-2016 : [[Pro Basketball Manager]] [http://www.dsogaming.com/news/pro-basketball-manager-2016-coming-this-january-on-pc-first-screenshots-unveiled/ announce of the new series] == History == BPM was developed by [[Victor Da Costa]].[http://www.metrofrance.com/lyon/un-lyonnais-cree-un-jeu-video-tout-seul/mmdb!9IO8KUaHTI4I/ Starting a video game all by himself] {{fr icon}} In an interview with Basketball News in March 2012, he explained that the game was developed while he was student at [[INSA Lyon]], before seeking an editor. The [[Umix Studios]] are composed by the people involved in the project (database and design).[http://ilovebasket.com/index.php?2011/11/10/752-basket-pro-management Yoann Noblet's interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120122710/http://ilovebasket.com/index.php?2011%2F11%2F10%2F752-basket-pro-management |date=January 20, 2013 }} {{fr icon}}[http://gamingway.fr/interview-victor-da-costa-ceo-dumix-studios-et-createur-de-basketball-pro-management/ Victor DA COSTA's interview 2013 {{fr icon}}] == Concept == The principle is similar to the [[Football Manager|football management games]], the player is the coach and team manager. He must manage his starting lineup, recruitment, training of young players, the detection of new talent, training, implementation tactics, budget management, management the staff (assistant coach, physiotherapist, scouts, physical trainer), tactics and systems, management games. The game has a tactic management: it is possible to create your own systems by choosing the actions of each player at every moment. The Data Editor allows the player to modify the characteristics of any player / team / coach. The game is available in French and English. The game has twenty playable championships, including four in France. The [[NBA]] has been added in updates a few weeks after the release of the 2012 version.[http://www.playitlive.fr/2012/02/la-ligue-americaine-aussi-dans-basketball-pro-management-2012/ NBA Addition] {{fr icon}} In 2012, the game developers have proposed updates to fix reported bugs on the forum and to add some features asked by the players. == Versions == === 2012 === The 2012 version (for the 2011-2012 season) first announced in fall 2011 was finally released on January 12, 2012. Critical opinion is generally good and often highlights the potential of the game.[http://www.jeuxvideo.com/articles/0001/00016401-basketball-pro-management-2012-test.htm Basketball Pro Management 2012 on JeuxVideo.com] {{fr icon}}[http://www.gamekult.com/jeux/basketball-pro-management-2012-J112574.html Basketball Pro Management 2012 on GameKult.com] {{fr icon}}[http://www.moddb.com/games/basketball-pro-management-2012 Basketball Pro Management 2012 on Moddb.com] In May 2012, the game has been released on CD via [[Tradewest]].[http://www.jeuxvideo.com/news/2012/00057542-basketball-pro-management-2012-dans-les-bacs.htm CD version for BPM] {{fr icon}} === 2013 === The 2013 version was scheduled for the last quarter of 2012.[http://www.posterdunk.com/basketball-pro-management-en-route-vers-2013/ Victor Da Costa on PosterDunk.com Part I] {{fr icon}} After several postponements, the game was finally released on February 15, 2013[http://www.posterdunk.com/basketball-pro-management-2013-presentation-et-analyse/ Victor Da Costa on PosterDunk.com Part II] {{fr icon}} with new features,[http://www.basketball-pro-management.com/40-liste-nouveautes.html New features on BPM 2013] {{fr icon}} the main ones are : * Optimized loading time * Improved simulations (AI vs. AI and AI vs player) * New way to create a team from A to Z * Full review of the interface * European Cups * Addition of transfer / loan * Individual Awards for players * Injury Management === 2014 === The 2014 version was announced on March 25, 2013. It was released on December 12, 2013. it contains a lot of new features such as US Universities, women teams or a new game engine. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.basketball-pro-management.com}} {{portal bar|Video games|2010s}} [[Category:Video game franchises introduced in 2012]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] [[Category:Basketball video games]] [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]] [[Category:Fangames]] [[Category:Sports management video games]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = DJ Carl Blaze | image = DJ Carl Blaze.jpg | image_size = 240px | caption = | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = Carlos Rivera | birth_date = {{birth date|1976|11|15}} |birth_place =[[New York City, New York|New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2006|12|23|1976|11|15}} |death_place =[[Harlem, New York|Harlem]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | origin = [[New York City, New York]] | instrument = [[Phonograph|Turntables]] | alias = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]], [[R&B]] | occupation = [[DJ]] | years_active = | label = | associated_acts = | website = [https://myspace.com/djcarlblazetribute Carl Blaze] on [[Myspace]] }} '''DJ Carl Blaze''' (born '''Carlos Rivera'''; November 15, 1976 - December 23, 2006) was an [[United States|American]] [[DJ]] of [[Dominican Republic|Dominican]] descent on New York City's Hip-Hop and R&B [[radio station]] [[WWPR-FM|Power 105.1]] for over three years. He hosted many parties and was a DJ for several [[Nightclub|clubs]] throughout [[New York City]]. Rivera was born in the [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]] section of [[New York City]].
==Death== On December 7, 2006 Carl Blaze was the victim of a fatal shooting outside an apartment building near the Inwood section of Manhattan where he was said to have been shot 12 to 16 times at about 4:30 am. Sources say that a [[diamond]] chain was stolen from him at the scene. The chain was said to be worth roughly around [[Dollar|$]]20,000-$25,000. He was taken to [[Harlem Hospital Center]], where he died Saturday, December 23. No arrest has been made and the investigation into the shooting is ongoing.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE3DF1E31F937A15751C1A9609C8B63 NYTimes] retrieved 6th June 2010</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Carlson|first=Jen|title=DJ Carl Blaze Dies from Shooting|url=http://gothamist.com/2006/12/23/dj_carl_blaze_d.php|newspaper=Gothamist|date=December 23, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717145910/http://gothamist.com/2006/12/23/dj_carl_blaze_d.php|archivedate=July 17, 2009|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://myspace.com/djcarlblazetribute Carl Blaze] on [[Myspace]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blaze, Carl}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]]

{{Spanish name|Capristán|García}} {{COI|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Carmencita Lara | image = Carmencita_Lara.png | image_size = | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Julia Rosa Capristán García | alias = ''La Reina de las Provincias''
''La Dama de los Valses Tristes''
''La Reina de la Rockola'' | birth_place = [[Paiján]], Peru | birth_date = {{birth date|1926|10|08|df=y}} | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|09|18|1926|10|08|df=y}} | instrument = [[Vocals]] | genre = [[Peruvian waltz]]
[[Marinera]]

[[Harawi (genre)|Harawi]]

Los Embajadores Criollos
Víctor Lara }} '''Julia Rosa Capristán García''' (8 October 1926 – 18 September 2018), better known by [[stage name]] '''Carmencita Lara''', was a Peruvian singer of waltzes, huaynos, marineras, polkas and pasillo. She is considered by many Peruvians referring to the perfect music to "drown the sorrows". Obituaries recognized the sharp tone of her voice, her particular interpretation and the accompaniment of the accordion of [[Víctor Lara]].[https://elcomercio.pe/luces/musica/fallecio-cantante-carmencita-lara-video-noticia-nndc-558869 Carmencita Lara: falleció cantante peruana a los 91 años] {{es icon}}[http://www.vocesdelimanorte.com/noticias/Distrito_de_Comas_declara_Hijos_Predilectos_a_Carmencita_Lara_y-a-su-esposo_Victor_Lara_Vasquez_por_difusion_de_musica_peruana.html COMAS DECLARO HOY "HIJOS PREDILECTOS" A "CARMENCITA LARA" Y A SU ESPOSO VÍCTOR LARA VÁSQUEZ] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216084659/http://www.vocesdelimanorte.com/noticias/Distrito_de_Comas_declara_Hijos_Predilectos_a_Carmencita_Lara_y-a-su-esposo_Victor_Lara_Vasquez_por_difusion_de_musica_peruana.html# |date=2013-02-16 }} {{es icon}}[https://rpp.pe/musica/conciertos/carmencita-lara-celebra-88-anos-de-vida-cantandole-al-peru-noticia-732085 Carmencita Lara celebra 88 años de vida cantándole al Perú] {{es icon}} She began her first steps as an amateur singer at age 15, on several radio stations in [[Lima]], but professionally at age 18.[https://lainolvidable.pe/noticias/entretenimiento/trayectoria-musical-de-carmencita-lara-29887#1 LA TRAYECTORIA MUSICAL DE CARMENCITA LARA] {{es icon}} Doña Julia and Don Víctor met in 1948, in [[Miraflores District, Lima|Miraflores]], when she was looking for a piano teacher. Since then, he stayed with her.[https://elcomercio.pe/luces/musica/carmencita-lara-reina-rockolas-cumple-hoy-88-anos-178263 Carmencita Lara, la reina de las rockolas, cumple hoy 88 años] {{es icon}} Víctor Lara was the one who came to baptize her with the pseudonym Carmencita Lara. At the moment that she had to register in a dependency of the state, Julia wanted to do it with the pseudonym of July García. The official replied that they did not register foreign artists there, implying that she did not like the name. Victor told Julia: - "Put Carmencita just like my mom and we complete with Lara".{{cn|date=September 2018}} She went through all the radio stations looking for an opportunity, until the first contract arrived. The contract was made with[Radio Excelsior, on 2 June 1955. The owner of the radio station had listened to her in a restaurant located next to the [[Plaza Mayor, Lima|Plaza de Armas]] where she went to sing. Her first recording was ''Olvídala amigo'', composition of the iqueño Luis R. Cueto, and of whom don Víctor was the one of the idea to record it. For this they used an accordion, [[cajón]] and double bass accompaniment instruments. This at the beginning of the 60s in a studio by the guitarist, Óscar Avilés.[https://rpp.pe/musica/nacional/cantante-carmencita-lara-fallecio-a-los-91-anos-noticia-1150570 Cantante Carmencita Lara falleció a los 91 años] {{es icon}}[http://www.teleamazonas.com/2018/09/peru-llora-la-muerte-de-carmencita-lara-2/ Perú llora la muerte de Carmencita Lara] {{es icon}}[https://www.last.fm/es/music/Carmencita+Lara/+wiki Biografía] {{es icon}} From there they came, ''Llora, llora corazón''[https://www.msn.com/es-ar/noticias/otras/restos-de-carmencita-lara-ser%C3%A1n-velados-en-su-vivienda-en-comas/vi-BBNwxPp Restos de Carmencita Lara serán velados en su vivienda en Comas] {{es icon}}, ''Indio'' by [[Alicia Maguiña]], singer-songwriter and researcher, who has always highlighted the value of Carmencita for the popular culture. Other tracks she recorded: ''Clavel Marchito'' by Armando Gonzáles, ''Milagro'' by Augusto Rojas Llerena and ''El Árbol de mi casa'' by Salvador Oda.[https://www.americatv.com.pe/noticias/espectaculos/cantante-carmencita-lara-sufrio-infarto-cerebral-n183367 Cantante Carmencita Lara sufrió infarto cerebral] {{es icon}} The couple of artists made a series of contributions to Peruvian music. She ended the stigma that the criollos do not sing huaynos. She was an innovator of the Peruvian waltz, not only in her way of interpreting it but also in the instrumental accompaniment she had. Don Víctor Lara, contributed incorporating for the first time the sound of the accordion and the battery in the Peruvian waltz. In addition, she devised the successful formula of fusing the female voice with the harp. She used ''¡Llora cholo, llora y sufre!'' as the lema in the beginnings of the concerts. ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_3qAwBXH8o4 Cuarto Poder Reportaje a Carmencita Lara] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lara, Carmencita}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Trujillo Province, Peru]] [[Category:Peruvian female singers]] [[Category:Peruvian music]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]] [[Category:21st-century women singers]]
