revision.text:
{{Infobox Theatre | name = Trepany House | image = | caption = Poster art by Travis Millard | address = Formerly at 4773 Hollywood Boulevard | city = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | country = {{USA}} | designation = | opened = 2012 | yearsactive = 2012-Current | rebuilt = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{url|http://trepanyhouse.org/}} }} '''Trepany House''' is a 501(c)3 Arts Organization founded by Amit Itelman in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://laist.com/2017/01/19/steve_allen_theater_cfi.php|title=The Eclectic Steve Allen Theater In Hollywood To Close In July|website=Laist.com|accessdate=12 April 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171231035408/http://laist.com/2017/01/19/steve_allen_theater_cfi.php|archivedate=31 December 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thekindland.com/culture/trepany-house-is-hollywoods-best-kept-comedy-secret-1121|title=Trepany House Is Hollywood's Best Kept Comedy Secret - KINDLAND|website=Thekindland.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} From its inception, it has been housed at [[the Steve Allen Theater]] within the [[Center for Inquiry]], Los Angeles property. ==Founding== Amit Itelman was the founding artistic director for the newly built [[Steve Allen Theater]] in 2003. In 2012, Amit Itelman founded Trepany House as a 501(c)3 Arts Organization, using the same Steve Allen Theater from CFI Los Angeles for performances.{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/event/the-last-night-of-the-steve-allen-theater-8808966|title=The Last Night of the Steve Allen Theater|website=L.A. Weekly|accessdate=12 April 2018}} Underground Comic artist [[Robert Crumb]] designed the Trepany House logo. Productions are a rotation of comedy, variety, music, magic, theatre, curiosities, and horror.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecomedybureau.com/post/157216386840/steve-allen-theater-torn-down-summer-trepany-house|title=The Steve Allen Theater/Center For Inquiry, Along with Trepany House, Will Be Torn Down This Summer|website=Thecomedybureau.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} LA Weekly wrote that- “Trepany has been a hub for subversive ideas and performance”,{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/los-felizs-trepany-house-at-steve-allen-theater-is-being-demolished-but-first-a-farewell-8676251|title=Los Feliz's Trepany House at Steve Allen Theater Is Being Demolished — But First, a Farewell|first=Lina|last=Lecaro|date=22 September 2017|website=Laweekly.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} Time Out stated- “fantastic, oddball shows… A true gem”,{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/los-angeles/theater/steve-allen-theater|title=Steve Allen Theater|website=Timeout.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} according to Boing Boing- “Trepany House consistently hosts the best performers and shows in Los Angeles”.{{cite web|url=https://boingboing.net/2016/11/04/in-la-this-sunday-you-can-hel.html|title=In LA this Sunday, you can help stop Mad Clown Disease! / Boing Boing|website=Boingboing.net|accessdate=12 April 2018}} Trepany House was in residence at [[the Steve Allen Theater]] until 2017. Trepany House now exists as an Arts Organization without a permanent residence. [[The Kids in the Hall]], 2HeadedDog, [[Brendon Small]], [[Ann Magnuson]], Re-Animator the Musical, Nevermore, [[Kate Micucci]], [[Rob Zabrecky]], Janet Klein, and [[Ron Lynch (comedian)|Ron Lynch]]’s Tomorrow! had Steve Allen Theater residences with Trepany House presenting. {{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/an-la-cult-comedians-insane-onstage-meta-sitcom-4184752|title=An L.A. Cult Comedian's Insane Onstage Meta-Sitcom|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|date=28 June 2013|website=Laweekly.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/event/ann-magnuson-8013281|title=Ann Magnuson|website=L.A. Weekly|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fangoria.com/new/re-animator-the-musical-revived-in-l-a|title=“RE-ANIMATOR: THE MUSICAL” Revived in L.A. - FANGORIA®|date=5 September 2015|website=Web.archive.com|accessdate=12 April 2018|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905121750/http://www.fangoria.com/new/re-animator-the-musical-revived-in-l-a|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/theater-to-see-in-la-this-week-including-jeff-goldblum-as-a-writing-teacher-2370503|title=Theater to See in L.A. This Week, Including Jeff Goldblum as a Writing Teacher|first=Steven Leigh|last=Morris|date=25 October 2012|website=Laweekly|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.songkick.com/artists/866881-kate-micucci|title=Kate Micucci|website=Songkick|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ==Shows premiered and developed at Trepany House== ''[[Force Majeure (tour)|Force Majeure]]'' - [[Eddie Izzard]]’s one man show, 11 show run. The tour went on to perform in 45 countries and all 50 U.S. States.{{cite web|url=http://www.scpr.org/programs/take-two/2015/04/28/42596/eddie-izzard-brings-his-force-majeur-to-the-hollyw/|title=Eddie Izzard brings his 'Force Majeur' to the Hollywood Bowl|date=28 April 2015|website=Scpr.org|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/go-eddie-go-2612455|title=Go Eddie Go|first=David|last=Cotner|date=13 December 2012|website=Laweekly.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ''FleischerFest'' - A full day of Fleischer cartoon’s, Fleischer themed performance, and a costume contest. Animation historian [[Jerry Beck]] interviewed Mark Fleischer, Janet Klein led a sing a long, and [[Puddles Pity Party]] performed.{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/fleischerfest-5343994|title=Los Angeles Arts and Culture News - L.A. Weekly|website=L.A. Weekly|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2015/01/this-weekend-fleischer-fest-cartoonmusic-marathon-in-hollywood-123657/#|title=This Weekend: “FLEISCHER-FEST” Cartoon/Music Marathon In Hollywood|first=Jerry|last=Beck|date=20 January 2015|website=Indiwwire.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-puddles-pity-party-clown-troubador-trepany-house-20150120-story.html|title=Puddles: Sad clown, big voice|first=Gerrick D.|last=Kennedy|website=latimes.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ''The Top Secret Brendon Small Experiment''. The show starring [[Brendon Small]], is a staged sitcom, where every week is a different episode.
''Re-Animator:The Musical'' {{cite web|url=http://www.fangoria.com/new/re-animator-the-musical-revived-in-l-a/|title=“RE-ANIMATOR: THE MUSICAL” Revived in L.A. - FANGORIA®|date=5 September 2015|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=12 April 2018|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905121750/http://www.fangoria.com/new/re-animator-the-musical-revived-in-l-a/|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=}}
''The Birthday Boys'' - Sketch Comedy show directed by [[Bob Odenkirk]] which was turned into a series on IFC. ''Puppetzilla Puppet Slam'' Puppetzilla- The LA Puppet Guild’s recurring Puppetslam which featured experimental puppet performances."{{cite web|url=http://laist.com/2017/10/05/weekend_planner_100517.php|title=Weekend Planner: 20 Of The Coolest Events Happening In Los Angeles|website=Laist.com|accessdate=12 April 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171113070301/http://laist.com/2017/10/05/weekend_planner_100517.php|archivedate=13 November 2017|df=}} ''Mel Gordon Mondo Lectures'' - University of California, Berkeley Professor Mel Gordon’s numerous lectures including Sex Magic and the Occult; [[Erik Jan Hanussen]], Hitler’s Jewish Clairvoyant; Anita Berber, the Dancer of Depravity, and more.{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/a-day-of-weimar-three-illustrated-lectures-on-sex-and-the-occult-in-pre-war-berlin-2175474|title=A Day of Weimar: Three Illustrated Lectures on Sex and the Occult in Pre-War Berlin|first=Libby|last=Molyneaux|date=21 June 2012|website=Laweekly.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ''With Bob and David'' - Mr. Show reunion to workshop material for [[Netflix]]’s With Bob and Dave, featuring [[Bob Odenkirk]] and [[David Cross]].(33) ''Firesign Theatre’s 50th Anniversary'' - With Firesign Theatre founders [[David Ossman]] and [[Philip Proctor]]. (34)[http://dola.com/events/2016/11/17/the-firesign-theatre-s-surprise-50th-birthday-party] {{dead link|date=April 2018}} ''Night Talk'' - A sex positive talk show hosted by [[Martin Starr]], with guests [[Mike Judge]] and [[Paul Scheer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/event/night-talk-with-martin-starr-6451568|title=Night Talk with Martin Starr|website=L.A. Weekly|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ''For Drummers Only'' - Joe Wong’s Trap Set and [[Fred Armisen]]’s comedy show devoted to drumming. Guests included [[Clem Burke]] from [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]] and [[Jack Black]].{{cite web|url=https://www.moderndrummer.com/2017/05/trap-set-presents-evening-comedy-drumming-starring-fred-armisen-friends/|title=The Trap Set Presents An Evening of Comedy and Drumming Starring Fred Armisen and Friends - Modern Drummer Magazine|date=11 May 2017|website=Moderndrummer.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ''The Secret History of Gwar'' - Performance and presentation by [[Hunter Jackson]], [[Techno Destructo]] from [[Gwar]].{{cite web|url=https://m.tix.com/Event.aspx?EventCode=718485|title=Ticket Sales - Secret Origins of Gwar at Trepany House on Saturday, February 21, 2015|website=m.tix.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ''The Occult Origins of Wonder Woman'' - A multi media presentation exploring the mythology and occult references present in the Wonder Woman cannon, by Maja D’Oust and Ron Rege Jr.{{cite web|url=https://us.eventbu.com/los-angeles/occult-origins-of-wonder-woman-w-ron-rege-jr-maja-d-aoust/2829273|title=The Occult Origins of Wonder Woman w/Ron Rege Jr & Maja D’Aoust - event - Los Angeles|website=Eventbu.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} == Selected stand up comedy == [[Bill Burr]], [[Laura Kightlinger]], and [[Marc Maron]] developed material in many full-length show residences.{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/los-angeles/things-to-do/things-to-do-in-los-feliz|title=The best things to do in Los Feliz|website=Timeout.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} Maron also recorded [[List_of_WTF_with_Marc_Maron_episodes]]. [[Jerrod Carmichael]] performed full-length shows, including the Carmichael Show live, performing alongside [[Tiffany Haddish]] and [[David Alan Grier]].{{cite web|url=https://trepanyhouse.tix.com/Event.aspx?EventCode=595749|title=Ticket Sales - An Evening of Stand Up with Jerrod Carmichael at Trepany House on Wednesday, August 28, 2013|website=Trepanyhouse.tix.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tix.com/Event.aspx?EventCode=943354|title=Ticket Sales - Jerrod Carmichael and the cast of the Carmichael Show at Trepany House on Friday, January 27, 2017|website=Tix.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} == Selected screenings == The Shining Backwards and Forwards, screening the Shining superimposed by the Shining running in reverse; conceived by John Fell Ryan.{{cite web|url=http://www.lamag.com/event/the-shining-forwards-and-backwards/|title=The Shining Forwards and Backwards - Los Angeles Magazine|website=Lamag.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wherevent.com/detail/Amit-Itelman-The-Shining-Forwards-and-Backwards|title=The Shining Forwards and Backwards|website=Wherevent.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} The Nightmare with a sleep paralysis panel featuring director Rodney Ascher and Sleep Paralysis Expert Dr. Brian Sharpless;[http://dola.com/events/2015/9/9/the-nightmare] {{dead link|date=April 2018}} Metropolis with a live score;{{cite web|url=http://losangeles.eventful.com/events/metropolis-/E0-001-103612604-0|title=Metropolis|website=Eventful|accessdate=12 April 2018}} Eggshells & The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, with the [[Tobe Hooper]] Appreciation Panel featuring [[Mick Garris]], [[Stuart Gordon]], and [[John Landis]].{{cite web|url=https://us.eventbu.com/city/eggshells-texas-chainsaw-massacre-w-landis-garris-and-gordon/5986641|title=Eggshells & Texas Chainsaw Massacre w/ Landis, Garris and Gordon - event|website=Eventbu.com|accessdate=12 April 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord missing|Los Angeles County, California}} [[Category:Theatres in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Comedy clubs in California]] [[Category:Variety shows]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2016}} [[File:Videoc.jpg|thumb|200px|Video Classics logo]] '''Video Classics''' was one of the first major [[Home video|Home Video]] Distributors in Australia.
Between 1979 and 1984, Video Classics was one of the leading names in Australian home video and claimed to have "Australia'sand us largest range of quality video movies"like fletch lives
At first the different [[Videocassette recorder#History|video formats]] that Video Classics advertised they duplicated was definitive of the formats on the market at the time, which included [[VHS]], [[Betamax]], [[Video 2000|Phillips]], Grundig and [[U-matic]], whether or not they actually duplicated onto any formats other than VHS or Beta is questionable though, By 1981 their advertising had reduced the list to just VHS and Beta.
Video Classics both rented their tapes and sold them with Prices that started at $69.95 (which was lowered to $49.95 by 1981) for sale, or rental prices being $9.90 overnight, $14.90 per week and $40 for three tapes per month.
In Addition to their own library of tapes, Video Classics also distributed tapes for other video labels including The Nostalgia Merchant, Sports World Cinema, VCL, [[Media Home Entertainment|Media]], Electric Blue, Wizard Video, Movies at Midnight, and Filmways.
Video Classics floated on the stock exchange for $1.15 million, but crashed spectacularly in 1984 leading to the company's demise.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:VideoClassicsBillCollins.jpg]] -->
==External links== * [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19860414&id=FgYRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MegDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3154,9980506 1986 Sydney Morning Herald article on Home Video] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927000037/http://www.tisn.gov.au/agd/WWW/rwpattach.nsf/viewasattachmentPersonal/(CFD7369FCAE9B8F32F341DBE097801FF)~f.pdf/$file/f.pdf Early Australian Home Video Document]

{{for|a video library|Vidéothèque}} '''Video Library''' was a publicly traded [[video rental shop]] based in [[San Diego, California]]. It had 43 corporate stores from 1979 through 1989 before they were acquired and converted into [[Blockbuster Video]] in 1989.
==History== Video Library made its [[Initial public offering|initial public stock offering]] in mid-1985.
Video Library was owned by Founder and President and Chief Executive Barry L. Rosenblatt, Chairman [[Roy Keith Black]], and shareholder Pauline Sussman. As part of the acquisition deal, the three received Blockbuster stock valued at $66.4 million. At the time of the acquisition, Blockbuster Video operated 58 company-owned and franchised Blockbuster Video Superstores.
Video Library reported $11.9 million in revenue for the third quarter of Sept. 1987.
==External links== * [http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Blockbuster-Inc-Company-History.html] at Blockbuster History * [http://articles.latimes.com/1988-02-17/business/fi-29219_1_smaller-video-library "Blockbuster to Buy Video Library for $6.4 Million" 1988-02-17. Retrieved 2017-07-28.] * [http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-6521471.html "Video Power Plays on Availability." 1986-01-27 San Diego Business Journal. Retrieved 2010-02-07.] * [http://articles.latimes.com/1987-11-17/business/fi-22140_1 "Video Library Goes Public." 1987-11-17. Los Angeles Times. Retrieved 2010-02-07.]
{{Video rental shops}}

{{original research|date=August 2015}}
[[File:FC-Twin-Console-Set-H.jpg|thumb|right|The [[FC Twin]], a popular clone system compatible with game cartridges for the original [[Nintendo Entertainment System]] and the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]].]]
A '''video game clone''' is either a [[video game]] (or series) which is very similar to or heavily inspired by a previous popular game or series.
The term is usually derogatory, implying a lack of originality and creativity; however, an intentional clone may be anything from a "[[ripoff]]" to an honorary [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to its [[wiktionary:exemplar#Noun|exemplar]]. Accusing a game of being a clone carries the implication that its developers or publishers try to profit off of the exemplar's success. In particularly bad cases this may be seen as a form of [[plagiarism]] or [[fraud]] and could be taken to [[court]].
Cloning a game in digital marketplaces is common, because it is hard to prevent and easy to compete with existing games. Developers can copyright the graphics, title, story, and characters, but they cannot easily protect software design and game mechanics. A [[patent]] for the mechanics is possible, but acquiring one is expensive and time-consuming.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/12/technology/for-creators-of-video-games-a-faint-line-on-cloning.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all "For Creators of Games, a Faint Line on Cloning"] ''New York Times'', Chen, Brian X. March 11, 2012</ref>
==Video games==
===History=== {{cleanup rewrite|it is poorly organized and verbose|section|date=January 2018}} [[File:Neo Double Games.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Neo Double Games. This is an unofficial handheld game console cloning the look of a [[Nintendo DS]] and featuring simple, LED games.]] Within the field of video games, popular game concepts often lead to that concept becoming incorporated or expanded upon by other developers. In other cases, games may be developed with clear influence from one or more earlier games. Such derivations are not always considered clones though the term may be used to make a comparison between games. As copyright law does not protect gameplay concepts, the reuse of such ideas is generally considered acceptable. Games like ''[[Tetris]]'' and ''[[Breakout (video game)|Breakout]]''<ref>{{cite web | last =Nelson | first =Mark | title =Breaking Down Breakout: System And Level Design For Breakout-style Games | publisher =[[Gamasutra]] | url =http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/1630/breaking_down_breakout_system_and_.php?print=1 | accessdate =2007-11-29 }}</ref> inspired many games that used similar core concepts but expanded beyond that; the ''Breakout''-inspired ''[[Arkanoid]]'' itself inspired many other clones that built upon its unique additions to ''Breakout''. Gameplay elements of ''[[Street Fighter II]]'' and ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' became common gameplay elements in the [[fighting game]] genre,<ref name="egm_influential_sf2">{{cite web|last=Patterson|first=Eric L.|title=EGM Feature: The 5 Most Influential Japanese Games Day Four: Street Fighter II|url=http://www.egmnow.com/articles/news/egm-featurethe-5-most-influential-japanese-gamesday-four-street-fighter-ii/|work=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-02-21-how-hackers-reinvented-street-fighter-2|title=How hackers reinvented Street Fighter 2|date=21 February 2014|work=Eurogamer.net|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5860138/innovation-has-never-been-the-cornerstone-of-the-video-game-industry|title=Innovation Has Never Been the Cornerstone of the Video Game Industry|author=Scott Patterson|publisher=Gawker Media|work=Kotaku|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref> A large number of games that tried to capitalize on the success of the 3D adventure game ''[[Myst]]'' were grouped as "Myst clones".<ref>{{cite web|author=Parrish, Jeremy|url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3134600|title=When SCUMM Ruled the Earth|publisher=[[1UP.com]]|accessdate=May 2, 2008|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ffGEdT2d?url=http://www.1up.com/features/essential-50-myst|archivedate=February 29, 2016|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> Some [[video game genres]] are founded by archetypal games of which all subsequent similar games are considered derivatives; notably, early [[first-person shooters]] were often called "''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'' clones",<ref name="clones">Turner, Benjamin & Bowen, Kevin, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120712042757/http://archive.gamespy.com/articles/december03/doom/clones/index.shtml Bringin' in the DOOM Clones], ''GameSpy,'' December 11, 2003, Accessed February 19, 2009</ref> while the success of the open-world formula in ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' led to the genre of [[GTA clone]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/3762350.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |title=Hunt for Grand Theft Auto pirates |date=2004-10-21 |accessdate=2008-08-26}}</ref> The genre of [[endless runner]]s is based on the success and simplicity of the game ''[[Canabalt]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/dont-stop-the-game-that-conquered-smartphones | title = Don’t Stop: The Game That Conquered Smartphones | first = Simon | last = Parkin | date = 2013-06-07 | accessdate = 2015-10-20 | work = [[The New Yorker|New Yorker]] }}</ref> In these cases, games that are "clones" of another are generally not implied to have committed any intellectual property infractions, and otherwise considered legally acceptable practices, although calling such games clones is generally considered derogatory.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
True video games clones occur when competitors, on seeing the success of a video game title, attempt to compete by creating a near-copy of the existing game with similar assets and gameplay with little additional innovation; developer [[Jenova Chen]] compared the nature of these clones similar to [[plagiarism]] in which there is little attempt to distinguish the new work from the original.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2009/12/cloning-or-theft-ars-explores-game-design-with-jenova-chen/ | title = Cloning or theft? Ars explores game design with Jenova Chen | first = Andrew | last = Webster | date = 2009-12-06 | accessdate = 2015-10-20 | publisher = [[Ars Technica]] }}</ref> ''[[BYTE]]'' reported in December 1981 that at least eight clones of [[Atari, Inc.]]'s [[arcade game]] ''[[Asteroids (video game)|Asteroids]]'' existed for personal computers.<ref name="williams198112">{{cite news | url=https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1981-12/1981_12_BYTE_06-12_Computer_Games#page/n163/mode/2up | title=Battle of the Asteroids | work=BYTE | date=December 1981 | accessdate=12 August 2015 | author=Williams, Gregg | pages=163–165}}</ref> The magazine stated in December 1982 that that year "few games broke new ground in either design or format ... If the public really likes an idea, it is milked for all it's worth, and numerous clones of a different color soon crowd the shelves. That is, until the public stops buying or something better comes along. Companies who believe that microcomputer games are the [[hula hoop]] of the 1980s only want to play Quick Profit."<ref name="clark198212">{{cite news | url=https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1982-12/1982_12_BYTE_07-12_Game_Plan_1982#page/n7/mode/2up | title=The Play's the Thing | work=BYTE | date=December 1982 | accessdate=19 October 2013 | author=Clark, Pamela | pages=6}}</ref> Video game clones are seen by those developing them as low risk; knowing that a game or genre is popular, developing a clone of that game would appear to be a safe and quick investment, in contrast with developing a new title with unknown sales potential.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://techcrunch.com/2014/01/05/why-all-the-clones/ | title = Why all the Clones | publisher = [[TechCrunch]] | first = Tadhg | last = Kelly | date = 2014-01-05 | accessdate = 2015-10-20 }}</ref>
Such cloning of video games initially bore out from [[arcade video game|arcade]] games, buoyed by the success of that sector during its "[[Golden age of arcade video games|golden age]]" in the early 1980s. Cloning would continue as home video game consoles became popular, and in part, the number of clones being produced and saturating the market were considered part of the reason for the [[North American video game crash of 1983|video game market crash in 1983]].<ref name="clark198212"/> A new resurgence in cloned video games came with the rise of [[social network game]]s, typically which were offered as [[freemium]] titles to entice new players to play.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.adweek.com/socialtimes/clone-wars-what-copycats-really-do-to-the-social-games-industry/586137 | title = Clone Wars: What Copycats Really Do To The Social Games Industry | first = AJ | last = Glasser | date = 2011-07-27 | accessdate = 2015-10-20 | work = [[Adweek]] }}</ref>
More recently, the cost, ease and simplicity of the tools needed to develop [[mobile game]]s has made cloning in that sector a significant problem.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tassi|first1=Paul|title=Over Sixty 'Flappy Bird' Clones Hit Apple's App Store Every Single Day|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2014/03/06/over-sixty-flappy-bird-clones-hit-apples-app-store-every-single-day/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.develop-online.net/news/flappy-bird-creator-s-new-game-swing-copters-has-already-been-cloned-a-lot/0196811 | title = Flappy Bird creator's new game Swing Copters has already been cloned. A lot. | first = James | last = Batchlor | date = 2014-08-21 | accessdate = 2014-08-21 | work = [[Develop (magazine)|Develop]] }}</ref><ref name="Rigny">{{Cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2014/03/flappy-bird-clones/ | title = How to Make a No. 1 App With $99 and Three Hours of Work | first = Ryan | last = Rigny | date = 2014-03-05 | accessdate = 2014-03-05 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] }}</ref> For example, ''[[Flappy Bird]]'' had been cloned dozens of times due to programming code clearinghouses offering templated code to which others could easily add their own art assets.<ref name="Rigny"/> The creators of ''[[Threes!]]'' spent 14 months developing the game and tuning its mechanics, but the first clone was released 21 days after ''Threes!'' and the original was quickly overshadowed by ''[[2048 (video game)|2048]]'', a clone that was developed over a weekend.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://toucharcade.com/2014/03/27/developers-release-all-570-threes-emails/ | title = Cloned to Death: Developers Release all 570 Emails That Discussed the Development of 'Threes!' | first = Clement | last = Renaudin | publisher = Touch Arcade | date = 2014-03-27 | accessdate = 2014-03-28 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Rip-offs & Making Our Original Game|url=http://asherv.com/threes/threemails/}}</ref>
===Legal aspects=== In 1981 [[Atari, Inc.]] warned in full-page advertisements "Piracy: This Game is Over", stating that the company "will protect its rights by vigorously enforcing [its] [[Copyright and video games|copyrights]] and by taking appropriate action against unauthorized entities who reproduce or adapt substantial copies of ATARI games", like a home-computer clone.<ref name="byte198110">{{cite news | url=https://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1981-10/1981_10_BYTE_06-10_Local_Networks#page/n345/mode/2up | title=Atari Software / Piracy: This Game is Over. | work=BYTE | date=October 1981 | accessdate=16 March 2016 | pages=347 | type=advertisement}}</ref> In present-day law, it is nonetheless held that game mechanics of a video game are part of its software, and are [[software copyright|generally ineligible for copyright]].<ref name="guardian legal">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2011/dec/21/clone-wars-games-industry-plagiarism | title = Clone Wars: is plagiarism killing creativity in the games industry? | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2011-12-23 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | first = Simon | last = Parkin }}</ref> The United States Copyright Office specifically notes: "Copyright does not protect the idea for a game, its name or title, or the method or methods for playing it. Nor does copyright protect any idea, system, method, device, or trademark material involved in developing, merchandising, or playing a game. Once a game has been made public, nothing in the copyright law prevents others from developing another game based on similar principles."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.copyright.gov/fls/fl108.html | title = U.S. Copyright Office – Games | publisher = [[United States Copyright Office]] | accessdate = 2012-08-07 }}</ref> The underlying source code, and the game's artistic elements, including art, music, and dialog, can be protected by copyright law.<ref name="guardian legal"/> In the United Kingdom, "neither a game’s ‘look and feel’ nor its mechanics are protectable", according to Nicolas Murfett, a legal associate for Harbottle & Lewis, while the European Union has yet to come to a resolution on the matter.<ref name="develop legal">{{Cite web | url = http://www.develop-online.net/analysis/the-fight-against-app-clones/0197276 | title = Experts explain difficulties in policing mobile marketplaces | work = [[Develop (magazine)|Develop]] | date = 2014-09-05 | accessdate = 2014-09-05 | first = James | last = Batchelor }}</ref> As an alternative, some elements of video game software have been protected through patents or trademarks.<ref name="develop legal"/><ref>{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2008/03/patents-on-video-game-mechanics-may-strangle-innovation/ | title = Patents on video game mechanics to strangle innovation, fun | date = 2008-03-09 | accessdate = 2012-08-10 | first = Ben | last = Kuchera | publisher = Ars Technica }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3562/the_designers_notebook_damn_all_.php | title = The Designer's Notebook: Damn All Gameplay Patents! | first = Earnst | last = Adams | date = 2008-03-05 | accessdate = 2012-08-10 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/1735/the_ten_most_important_video_game_.php | title = The Ten Most Important Video Game Patents | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | date = 2007-01-19 | accessdate = 2012-08-10 | first = Steve | last = Chang | first2 = Ross | last2 = Dannenberg }}</ref>
It is generally recognized in the video game industry that borrowing mechanics from other games is common practice, and their widespread use would make them ineligible for legal copyright or patent protection.<ref name="guardian legal"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=26290 | title = Analysis: Clone Games & Fan Games – Legal Issues | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | date = 2009-12-09 | accessdate= 2012-08-07 | first = Mona | last = Ibrahim }}</ref> Courts also consider ''[[scènes à faire]]'' (French for "scenes that must be done") for a particular genre as uncopyrightable; games involving vampires, for example, would be expected to have elements of the vampire drinking blood and driving a stake through the vampire's heart to kill him.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases"/> Up until 2012, courts were reluctant to find for copyright infringement of clones; attorney Stephen C. McArthur, writing for ''[[Gamasutra]]'', said that courts opted to take a more lax view to balance innovation in the industry and prevent overzealous copyright protection that could have one company claim copyright on an entire genre of games.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases"/>
A shift in legal options for developers to challenge clones arose from the 2012 federal court decision that ruled in favor of the [[Tetris Company]], the owners of the ''Tetris'' copyright, over the clone ''Mino'' which used the same gameplay as ''Tetris'' but with different art assets. The developers for ''Mino'' has cited in their defense that they only used the uncopyrightable gameplay elements of ''Tetris'' in ''Mino''. The court ruled that copyright law was in favor of the Tetris Company's claim, as the gameplay was copied without changes, and while the art assets were new, the "look and feel" of ''Mino'' could be easily confused for that of ''Tetris''.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases"/><ref name="arstech tetris">{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2012/06/defining-tetris-how-courts-judge-gaming-clones | title = Defining Tetris: How courts judge gaming clones | first = Kyle | last = Orland | date = 2012-06-20 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | publisher = Ars Technica }}</ref> This decision serves as case law for other developers to fend off "look-and-feel" clones.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack C. Schecter|url=http://www.sunsteinlaw.com/publications-news/news-letters/2012/06/Schecter_201206.html|title=Grand Theft Video: Judge Gives Gamemakers Hope for Combating Clones|publisher=sunsteinlaw.com|date=2012-06-18 |accessdate=2012-06-19|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109035334/http://www.sunsteinlaw.com/publications-news/news-letters/2012/06/Schecter_201206.html|archivedate=2012-11-09|df=}}</ref> Similarly, SpryFox LLC, the developers of the mobile game ''[[Triple Town]]'', successfully defended their game from a clone, ''Yeti Town'', developed by 6Waves, through court settlement after the judge gave initially rulings in favor of SpryFox; these rulings suggested that there was copyright protection on the gameplay mechanics despite drastic differences in the games' art assets, though other factors, such as prior agreements between SpryFox and 6Waves, may have also been involved.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases">{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/187385/clone_wars_the_six_most_important_.php | title = Clone Wars: The Six Most Important Cases Every Game Developer Should Know | first = Stephen | last = McArthur | date = 2013-02-27 | accessdate = 2013-02-27 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref>
Other notable legal actions involving video game clones include: * In 1982, Atari brought a lawsuit against [[Amusement World]], claiming that the arcade game ''Meteos'' violated Atari's copyright on ''[[Asteroids (video game)|Asteroids]]''. Though the court identified twenty-two similarities in the game mechanics, it ruled against Atari citing these elements as ''scènes à faire'' for games about shooting at asteroids.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases"/> * [[Atari]] sought an injunction in 1982 to block the sale of ''[[Munchkin (video game)|K.C. Munchkin]]'' for the [[Magnavox Odyssey²|Phillips-Magnavox Odyssey²]], citing excessive similarities to its [[Pac-Man (Atari 2600)|Atari 2600 version of ''Pac-Man'']]. Though the court initially denied the injunction, Atari won on appeal; the court noted that though ''K.C. Munchkin'' offered different features such as moving walls and fewer dots in the maze to eat, "substantial parts were lifted; no plagiarist can excuse the wrong by showing how much of his work he did not pirate".<ref name="wired ea zynga">{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2012/08/ea-sues-zynga | title = CourtVille: Why Unclear Laws Put EA v. Zynga Up for Grabs | first = Chris | last = Kohler | date =2012-08-08 | accessdate =2012-08-08 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] }}</ref> * [[Data East]] sued [[Epyx]] over copyright violations from Data East's ''[[Karate Champ]]'' used in Epyx's ''World Karate Championship''. Similar to ''Asteroids'' vs. ''Meteors'', the court ruled in favor of Epyx, stating that while many elements were similar, they were necessary as part of karate championship-based game, and the remaining copyrightable elements were substantially different.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases"/> * [[Capcom]] filed a 1994 lawsuit against [[Data East]] over their fighting game, ''[[Fighter's History]]'', which Capcom claimed cloned characters, art assets, and move sets from ''[[Street Fighter II]]''. The court ruled against Capcom, stating that while some elements may have been similar, no direct measure of willful copying could be found; the court further found that many of the characters in ''Street Fighter II'' were already based on public domain stereotypical fighters, and were ineligible for copyright protection.<ref name="gamasutra 6 cases"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.davis.ca/en/entry/video-game-law/street-fighter-ii-vs-fighters-history/ | title = Street Fighter II Vs. Fighter's History | first = Chris | last = Bennett | date = 1994-03-18 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | publisher = [[Davis LLP]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.1up.com/features/20-years-street-fighter | title = Twenty Years of Whoop-Ass | date = 2007-12-11 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | first = Naida | last = Oxford | publisher = [[1UP.com]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dannenberg |first=Ross |url=http://www.patentarcade.com/2005/08/case-capcom-v-data-east-nd-cal-1994-c.html |title=Case: Capcom v. Data East (N.D. Cal. 1994) [C] |publisher=Patent Arcade |date=2005-08-29 |accessdate=2010-07-26}}</ref> * [[Sega]] had filed a 1998 United States patent for the gameplay concepts in ''[[Crazy Taxi (series)|Crazy Taxi]]''.<ref>{{ cite patent |country=US |number=6200138 |status=patent}}</ref> The company subsequently used that patent to sue [[Fox Interactive]] over their title ''[[The Simpsons: Road Rage]]'', citing that the latter game was developed to "deliberately copy and imitate" the ''Crazy Taxi'' game.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/130122/the_trouble_with_patents.php?page=1 | title = The Trouble With Patents | first = David | last = Sirlin | date = 2007-02-27 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref> The case was ultimately settled out of court.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.patentarcade.com/2010/07/case-analysis-sega-v-fox.html | title = Case Analysis: Sega v. Fox | publisher = Patent Arcade | date = 2010-07-12 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 }}</ref> [[File:Ea vs zynga lawsuit screenshot comparison.jpg|thumb|right|A comparison of in-game screenshots, published in EA's legal filings, of EA's ''The Sims Social'' (left) and Zynga's ''The Ville'', demonstrating the similarities in the games' art assets.]] * In August 2012, [[Electronic Arts]] (EA), via its [[Maxis]] division, put forth a lawsuit against [[Zynga]], claiming that its Facebook game, ''[[The Ville (video game)|The Ville]]'' was a ripoff of EA's own Facebook game, ''[[The Sims Social]]''. The lawsuit challenges that ''The Ville'' not only copies the gameplay mechanics of ''The Sims Social'', but also uses art and visual interface aspects that appear to be inspired by ''The Sims Social''. Zynga has long been criticized by the video game industry as cloning popular social and casual games from other developers,<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielnyegriffiths/2012/08/06/ea-sues-zynga-but-deeper-social-issues-threaten/ | title = EA Sues Zynga, But Deeper Social Issues Threaten | first = Daniel Nye | last = Griffen | date = 2012-08-06 | accessdate = 2012-08-07 | work = [[Forbes]] }}</ref><ref name="zynga clone">{{cite web | url = http://www.edge-online.com/features/how-zynga-cloned-its-way-success | title = How Zynga cloned its way to success | first = Nathan | last = Brown | date = 2012-01-25 | accessdate =2012-08-07 | work = [[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sfweekly.com/2010-09-08/news/farmvillains/ | title = FarmVillains | first= Peter | last =Jamison | date = 2010-09-08 | accessdate =2012-08-07 | work = [[SF Weekly]] }}</ref> a practice common throughout the social game genre.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://techcrunch.com/2012/08/04/zyngapocalypse-now-and-what-comes-next/ | title = Zyngapocalypse Now (And What Comes Next?) | first = Tadhg | last = Kelly | date =2012-08-04 | accessdate= 2012-08-07 | publisher = [[TechCrunch]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/blogs/TadhgKelly/20091218/3665/Zynga_and_the_End_of_the_Beginning.php | title = Zynga and the End of the Beginning | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] | date = 2009-12-18 | accessdate =2012-08-07 | first = Tadhg | last= Kelly }}</ref> In past cases, Zynga's clones have typically been from smaller developers without the monetary resources to pursue legal action (as in the case of ''[[Tiny Tower]]'' by [[NimbleBit]], which Zynga has cloned in their game, ''Dream Heights'') or that are willing to settle out of court (as in the case of Zynga's ''[[Mafia Wars]]'', which was accused of cloning David Maestri's ''[[Mob Wars]]'').<ref name="zynga clone"/> Pundits have noted that EA, unlike these previous developers, are financially backed to see the case to completion; EA themselves have stated in the lawsuit that "Maxis isn’t the first studio to claim that Zynga copied its creative product. But we are the studio that has the financial and corporate resources to stand up and do something about it."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2012/08/03/zynga-pokes-a-giant-ea-files-lawsuit-after-the-ville-clones-the-sims/ | title = Zynga Pokes a Giant: EA Files Lawsuit After The Ville Clones The Sims | date = 2012-08-03 | accessdate =2012-08-07 | work = [[Forbes]] | first = Paul | last = Tassi }}</ref> The two companies settled out of court on undisclosed terms in February 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/186789/EA_and_Zynga_settle_The_Ville_copycat_case_out_of_court.php | title = EA and Zynga settle The Ville copycat case out of court | first = Frank | last =Cifaldi | date = 2013-02-15 | accessdate = 2013-02-15 | publisher = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref>
More recently, with the popularity of social and mobile game stores like Apple's [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]] for iOS system and [[Google Play]] for Android-based systems, a large number of likely-infringing clones have begun appearing.<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/appsblog/2012/feb/03/apps-apple | title = Should Apple take more action against march of the iOS clones? | first = Stuart | last = Dredge | date = 2012-02-03 | accessdate =2012-08-10 | work = [[The Guardian]] }}</ref> While such storefronts typically include a review process before games and apps can be offered on them, these processes do not consider copyright infringement of other titles. Instead, they rely on the developer of the work that has been cloned to initiate a complaint regarding the clone, which may take time for review. The cloned apps often are purposely designed to resemble other popular apps by name or feel, luring away purchasers from the legitimate app, even after complaints have been filed.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://techcrunch.com/2011/12/06/can-we-stop-the-copycat-apps/ |title = Can We Stop The Copycat Apps? | first = Rip | last = Epsom | date =2011-12-11 | accessdate = 2012-08-10 | publisher = [[TechCrunch]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://techcrunch.com/2012/02/03/app-store-fakes/ | title = Apple Kicks Chart Topping Fakes Out Of App Store | first = John | last = Constine | date =2012-02-03 | accessdate = 2012-08-10 | publisher = [[TechCrunch]] }}</ref> Apple has released a tool to streamline claims of app clones to a team dedicated to handle these cases, helping to bring the two parties together to try to negotiate prior to action.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/apple/2012/09/apple-now-provides-online-tool-to-report-app-store-ripoffs/ | title = Apple now provides online tool to report App Store ripoffs | first = Chris | last = Foresman | date = 2012-09-04 | accessdate = 2012-09-04 | publisher = Ars Technica }}</ref> While Apple, Google, and Microsoft took steps to stem the mass of clones based on ''Swing Copters'' after its release, experts believe it is unlikely that these app stores will institute any type of proactive clone protection outside of clear copyright violations, and these experts stress the matter is better done by the developers and gaming community to assure the original developer is well known, protects their game assets on release, and gets the credit for the original game.<ref name="develop legal"/>
Another approach some companies have used to prevent clones is via [[trademarks]] as to prevent clones and knockoffs. Notably, [[King (company)|King]] have gotten a United States trademark on the word "Candy" in the area of video games to protect clones and player confusion for their game ''[[Candy Crush Saga]]''. They have also sought to block the use of the word "Saga" in the trademark filing of ''[[The Banner Saga]]'' for similar reasons, despite the games having no common elements.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/01/22/candy-crush-saga-dev-king-trademarks-the-word-candy | title = Candy Crush Saga Dev Goes After The Banner Saga | publisher = [[IGN]] | date = 2014-01-22 | accessdate = 2014-01-22 | first = Luke | last = Karmali }}</ref> Within the European Union, one can register for a [[European Union trade mark]] that includes multimedia elements, which would allow a developer or publisher to trademark a specific gameplay element that is novel from past games, providing a different route for them to protect their work from cloning. For example, [[Rebellion Developments]] filed to register its "Kill Cam" mechanic as a trademark from its series ''[[Sniper Elite]]'' in October 2017, though as of February 2018, the application is still being reviewed.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-02-19-multimedia-trademarks-kill-cloners | title = How multimedia trade marks could kill cloned games | first = Kostyantyn | last = Lobov | date = February 19, 2018 | accessdate = February 19, 2018 | work = [[GamesIndustry.biz]] }}</ref>

{{nihongo|吉本興業}} | logo = Yoshimoto mugendai.png | logo_size = 300px | foundation = April 22, 1932 | location_city = [[Osaka]] | location_country = | area_served = [[Japan]] | industry = Entertainment industry
[[Production company]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = [[Japanese yen|¥]] 600 million | assets = [[Japanese yen|¥]] 61.7 billion | equity = | owner = Yoshimoto Creative Company | num_employees = 610 | divisions = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.yoshimoto.co.jp}} }} {{Nihongo|'''Yoshimoto Kogyo Co., Ltd.'''|吉本興業株式会社|Yoshimoto Kōgyō Kabushiki-gaisha}} is a major Japanese [[entertainment]] conglomerate, with its headquarters in [[Osaka]]. It was founded in 1912 as a [[Rakugo|traditional theatre]], and has since grown to be one of the most influential companies in Japan, employing most of Japan's popular [[owarai]] (comedy) talent, producing and promoting the shows they appear in.Martin, Alex, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100518i1.html YOSHIMOTO, Entertaining the nation: For almost 100 years, Yoshimoto has been clearinghouse for comics]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', May 18, 2010, p. 3. ==History== Yoshimoto is said to be almost single-handedly responsible for the development of Japanese [[manzai]] after World War II and, in fact, the [[kanji]] that are now used for the word ''manzai'' were introduced by Yoshimoto in 1933, spelling a new era for the comedy style. Although pure ''manzai'' is no longer the dominant form of entertainment in Japan, Yoshimoto's influence remains and the spirit of ''manzai'' lives on in modern Japanese comedy, as can be seen by the prevalence of the [[Kansai dialect]] in many ''owarai'' productions. The current director of Yoshimoto is [[Isao Yoshino]], who replaced the long-standing ex-senior director Masao Kimura in January 2005. Kimura had been part of the company since entering in 1969, and in the 35 plus years that Kimura worked with Yoshimoto, it expanded greatly and its reputation as a successful company grew enormously. Fresh out of university, Yoshimoto is still the goal for many young comedians, and many of them hope to be accepted into the 'New Star Creation' school in Osaka, or one of others across Japan. Yoshimoto now boasts more than 650 entertainers, possibly the most famous being the ''owarai'' ''kombi'' (duo) [[Downtown (Owarai)|Downtown]], successors of the ''manzai'' duo [[Yasu-Kiyo]] in the 1980s. As in much of Japanese culture, there exists a strong bond between [[senpai]] (senior) and [[kōhai]] (junior) members of the entertainment industry. Many lower level employees of Yoshimoto do not receive full salaries but rather benefit from the advice and guidance of senior members of the company. ==Retained acts== ===Solo=== *[[Sanma Akashiya]] 明石家 さんま *[[Koji Imada|Kōji Imada]] 今田耕司 *[[Koji Higashino]] 東野 幸治 *[[Takashi Fujii (comedian)|Takashi Fujii]] 藤井隆 *[[Hanako Yamada]] 山田花子 *[[Shoji Murakami]] 村上ショージ *[[Hōsei Tsukitei]]　月亭方正 *[[Jimmy Onishi]]　ジミー大西 ===Duo=== *[[Downtown (Owarai)|Downtown]] ダウンタウン ([[Masatoshi Hamada]] and [[Hitoshi Matsumoto]]) *[[Ninety-nine (Owarai)|Ninety-nine]] ナインティナイン ([[Takashi Okamura (comedian)|Takashi Okamura]] and [[Hiroyuki Yabe]]) *[[Rozan (Owarai)|Rozan]] ロザン ([[Fuminori Ujihara]] and [[Hirofumi Suga]]) *[[London Boots]] ロンドンブーツ1号2号 ([[Atsushi Tamura]] and [[Ryō Tamura (London Boots)|Ryō Tamura]]) *[[Tutorial]] チュートリアル ([[Yoshimi Tokui]] and [[Mitsunori Fukuda]]) *[[Kirin (Owarai)|Kirin]] 麒麟 ([[Akira Kawashima]] and [[Hiroshi Tamura]]) *[[Harisenbon]] ハリセンボン ([[Haruka Minowa]] and [[Haruna Kondou]]) *[[Penalty (Owarai)|Penalty]] ペナルティ (Hide and Wakki) *[[Regular (Owarai)|Regular]] レギュラー ([[Kōta Matsumoto]] and [[Akihiro Nishikawa]]) *[[Jicho Kacho|Jichō Kachō]] 次長課長 ([[Junichi Kōmoto]] and [[Satoshi Inoue (comedian)|Satoshi Inoue]]) *[[130R]] ([[Hon Kon (Owarai)|Hon Kon]] and [[Itsuji Itao]]) *[[License (Owarai)|License]] ライセンス (Kazuhiro Fujiwara and Takafumi Inomoto) *[[Cocorico (comedy duo)|Cocorico]] ココリコ (Shōzō Endō and Naoki Tanaka) *{{Interlanguage link|Bad Boys (comedy duo)|ja|バッドボーイズ_(お笑いコンビ)|WD=}} ({{nihongo|バッドボーイズ}}) (Kiyoto Omizo and Masaki Sata) *{{Interlanguage link|Woman Rush Hour|ja|ウーマンラッシュアワー|WD=}} (Daisuke Muramoto & Paradise Nakagawa), Yoshimoto has been expanding its business in recent years, due to the so-called '''warai'' boom'. They now have their own comedy theme park in [[Otaru, Hokkaido]] and have begun signing the likes of musicians, producers, [[sportsperson|athlete]]s and singers alongside business with the Japanese ''owarai'' industry. ==Property== Yoshimoto Kogyo is the owner of a number of corporate offices and stages, most situated in the downtown areas of Osaka and Tokyo. The company has two headquarters, Osaka HQ (大阪本部) and Tokyo HQ (東京本部) and a number of stages, namely [[Lumine the Yoshimoto]] (ルミネtheよしもと), 5 up Yoshimoto (5upよしもと), [[NMB48]] Theater (NMB48劇場), Nanba Grand Kagetsu (なんばグランド花月), and a new stage in the popular [[Shibuya, Tokyo|Shibuya]] district of Tokyo, [[Yoshimoto Mugendai Hall]] (ヨシモト∞ホール). Yoshimoto also had a comedy museum in downtown Osaka called [[Yoshimoto Shotengai|Yoshimoto Shōtengai]] (吉本笑店街), but it closed in 2009. ==Other Assets== Yoshimoto Kogyo also owns a [[community radio|community]] [[Frequency modulation|FM]] [[radio station]], [http://www.yesfm.jp/ YES-fm 78.1] (callsign: JOZZ7AF-FM), based in [[Namba]], [[Osaka]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.japan-zone.com/modern/yoshimoto.shtml Japan-zone] ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.yoshimoto.co.jp/ Yoshimoto Kogyo] - Official site in Japanese *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060618171148/http://www.fandango.co.jp/mugendai/world/index.html Fandango] - Small English Yoshimoto profile *[http://laff.jp/ Laff.jp] - Yoshimoto Kogyo's owarai talents blog site [[Category:Entertainment companies of Japan]] [[Category:Performing arts in Japan]] [[Category:Companies based in Osaka Prefecture]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1912]] [[Category:1912 establishments in Japan]]
